This command installs the package for the upgraded agent and removes older versions. If the upgrade cannot be completed, the system reverts to the previous installed version so that the service can continue running.

To perform an upgrade, run the following command:

rpm -Uvh ciphercloud-logagent-<version> -centos7.86_64rpm

To verify the upgrade version, run the following command:

rpm -qa | grep ciphercloud-logagent


Starting, stopping, and checking the status of log agent services‌

To start a log agent, enter the following command:

systemctl start ciphercloud-logagent

To stop a log agent, enter the following command:

systemctl stop ciphercloud-logagent

To check the status of a log agent, enter the following command:

systemctl status ciphercloud-logagent


Creating and configuring key servers‌

The following sections provide instructions for creating a new key server and for downloading HKMS software for connecting a key server to the Management Server.


Creating a new key server on the cloud‌

By default, your deployment includes a cloud-based key server. You can use this key server to store keys on the cloud. You can create an additional key server for on-premise storage of keys.

To create a new key server:

  1. Go to Administration > Enterprise Integration > Key Server Management and click New.

  2. Enter a Key Server Name and a Description (both required).

  3. Select an HKMS CA Certificate from the list. This is the trusted CA certificate used for creating client HKMS certificates.

  4. Enter one or more Authorized IP Addresses for which connection will be permitted. For multiple addresses, separate each address with a comma.

  5. Click Save.

    The key server is added to the Key Server Management page. Its status is Disconnected (as indicated by the red connector icon) until it is connected to the Management Server. Connection includes two procedures:

    • Downloading and installing the Hybrid Key Management (HKMS) RPM file

    • Enabling connectivity with the Management Server from the on-premise Management Console The following sections provide instructions for these procedures.

Downloading and installing the HKMS RPM file‌

Before you can connect the key server to the Management Server, you must install the hybrid key management (HKMS) software.

  1. Go to Administration > System Settings > Downloads.

  2. Click the download icon for HKMS.

  3. Save the RPM file.

  4. Open the RPM file to begin the installation.

  5. Enter the following command:

Sudo yum install hkms-<version>.x86_64.rpm.

The system responds:

[root@pherur-centos ~]# yum install hkms-1.5.0-54.x86_64.rpm Loaded plugins: fastestmirror

Examining hkms-1.5.0-54.x86_64.rpm: hkms-1.5.0-54.x86_64 Marking hkms-1.5.0-54.x86_64.rpm to be installed Resolving Dependencies

There are unfinished transactions remaining. You might consider running yum-complete-transaction, or "yum-complete-transaction --cleanup-only" and "yum history redo last", first to finish them. If those don't work you'll have to try removing/installing packages by hand (maybe package-cleanup can help).

The program yum-complete-transaction is found in the yum-utils package.

--> Running transaction check

--> Package hkms.x86_64 0:1.5.0-54 will be installed

--> Finished Dependency Resolution Dependencies Resolved

======================================================================

Package Arch

Version Repository

Size

======================================================================

Installing:

hkms x86_64

1.5.0-54 /hkms-1.5.0-54.x86_64

173 M

Transaction Summary

======================================================================

Install 1 Package Total size: 173 M Installed size: 173 M Is this ok [y/d/N]:

  1. Enter Y to continue. Downloading packages: Running transaction check Running transaction test Transaction test succeeded Running transaction

executing - /usr/sbin/useradd -r -g hkms -c Hybrid Key Management Server - s /bin/nologin hkms

Installing : hkms-1.5.0-54.x86_64 1/1

192.168.227.107

====================================================================

CipherCloud has been successfully installed in /opt/ciphercloud/hkms Adding [Systemd] service support

Reloading Systemd daemon

Systemd service hkms has been installed and configured to be automatically started on system restart

Please use 'sudo systemctl start hkms' to start the service manually Please navigate to https://192.168.227.107:8443 to continue once started

Please note that a database server is required to configure the CipherCloud

======================================================================

Verifying : hkms-1.5.0-54.x86_64 1/1

Installed:

hkms.x86_64 0:1.5.0-54

Complete!

Once the HKMS software is installed, you will be prompted to initialize the HKMS server, the database, and the Notification Server.


Enabling connectivity for the on-premise key server‌

To connect the on-premise key server to a Management Server:

  1. From the on-premise Management Console, go to Administration > System Settings.

  2. Under Connectivity, choose Cloud Key Access Service. This page displays the information for the selected key server.

    • Key Server Name is the name used when the key server was created.

    • Cloud Service Hostname is the specified host name in a format similar to <tenant- hkms.ciphercloud.io>. Enter the exact hostname for the tenant.

    • Cloud service port – The port number for this configuration.

    • HKMS Server Token – The token generated when the Key Server was created.

    • Certificate – The certificate selected here must be a client certificate created by the same trusted CA specified in the Key Server Management page.

    • Time to Live – The duration (in seconds) after which the connection is refreshed.

  3. Click Save.

The key server is now connected and ready to store keys on-premise, as indicated by the green connector icon in the Key Server Management page.


Configuring an upstream proxy‌

From System Settings in the Management Console, you can create upstream proxy configurations to work with on-premise connector environments that include SEIM, EDLP, and Log Agent services.

The Upstream Proxy page lists the upstream proxy configurations you create.


Creating a new upstream proxy configuration in the Management Console‌

  1. Go to Administration > System Settings and select Upstream Proxy.

  2. Click New.

  3. Enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional) for the new configuration.

  4. Enter a Host name or IP address of the machine where you installed the agent (SIEM, EDLP, or Log Agent) for which you want to configure the upstream.

  5. Enter a Port number.

  6. (Optional) If you want to require authentication, click the Authentication toggle to enable it. The User Name and Password fields appear. Enter the username and password for authentication.

  7. Click Save. The new configuration is added to the list. You can now use this configuration for any on- premise connector environment you create that includes an SIEM, EDLP, or Log Agent service.

  8. Select the environment.

  9. Restart the configured agent on the host server.


Viewing details for an upstream proxy configuration‌

From the Upstream Proxy page, click the icon next to the name of the configuration you want to view.


Click Cancel to return to the list.


Modifying an upstream proxy configuration‌

  1. Click the pen icon in the Actions column for the configuration you want to modify.

  2. Edit the details as needed.



  3. Click Update to save the changes.


    Installing the on-premise connector with the upstream proxy‌

    Note This procedure is applicable for the following agents:

    • SIEM

    • EDLP

    • Log Agent

  1. From the Management Console, go to Administration > System Settings > Downloads and download the current on-premise connector.

  2. Install the on-premise connector as follows.

    • For rpm:

      sudo yum install ./<package>.rpm

    • For Debian:

      sudo apt install ./<package>.deb

      ==========================================================================

      CipherCloud node server has been successfully installed in /opt/ciphercloud/node-server.

      Adding [Systemd] service support Reloading Systemd daemon

      Systemd service node-server has been installed

      Please use 'sudo systemctl start node-server' to start the service manually

      ==========================================================================

      ============IMPORTANT=====================================================

      Please run 'sudo /opt/ciphercloud/node-server/install.sh' to configure the node server before starting it for the first time.

  3. Go to the node server directory.

    [root@localhost ~]# cd /opt/ciphercloud/node-server/

  4. Run install.sh.

    [root@localhost node-server]# ./install.sh

  5. Enter the Node Manager endpoint, Tenant Id, Node Server Unique Name and Node Server Token details.

    Initializing node-server install script. Please wait..

    Please enter Node Manager endpoint [wss://nm.ciphercloud.io:443/nodeManagement]:

    Node Manager endpoint: wss://nm.qa1.ciphercloud.in:443/nodeManagement Input Tenant Id: guzzi

    Input Node Server Unique Name: NODETest

    Input Node Server Token: SKJmP/XNC/lQJBN01RlETTuJoyGcyEGAjNGxAqEZru4= grep: ": No such file or directory

  6. Select Y to install with upstream proxy and enter the upstream proxy details. Note If you do not want to use the upstream proxy, specify N and press Enter. Does upstream proxy exist? [y/n]: y

    Input Host Name of upstream proxy server: 192.168.222.147 Input port number of upstream proxy server: 3128

  7. Enter the username and password if you want to enable the upstream proxy with authorization. Otherwise, press Enter.

    Input upstream proxy authorization - user name (Press enter key if no authorization required): test

    Input upstream proxy authorization - password: test@123 Adding new property ms.endpoint.

    Adding new property node.name.

    Adding new property node.token.plain. Adding new property node.nic.

    Adding new property ms.proxy.host. Adding new property ms.proxy.port. Adding new property ms.proxy.auth.user.

    Adding new property ms.proxy.auth.pwd.plain. Updating property logging.config

    Node server installation is done. Start node server using 'sudo service node-server start'.

  8. Start the Node Server.

[root@localhost node-server]# sudo service node-server start Started [9132]

Configuring the upstream proxy for on-premise deployments‌

For on-premise deployments, you can configure an upstream proxy and select the option for proxy authentication.


Creating and managing enterprise sites‌

You can inspect traffic from sites in your organization from which data is being sent to cloud applications such as Box, Salesforce, or Office 365 or to other Internet destinations. Each site definition you create directs traffic from that site to the Lookout security platform, where it is inspected and processed based on the security policies configured for the destination applications. For example, if your organization has four branch offices, you can configure a tunnel for each office that specifies how traffic will be directed from that site to the Lookout security platform before the data goes to its destination.

For each branch site for which you need to configure traffic steering, you can create a new enterprise site from the Management Console (Enterprise Integration > Enterprise Sites).



Creating a new enterprise site for traffic tunneling‌

Perform the following steps to configure traffic tunneling for each site in your organization.

  1. Go to Administration > Enterprise Integration > Enterprise Sites and click New.



  2. Enter these basic details.

    • Name and Description – Enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional) for the site.

    • Location -- Enter location information (country and state or province as applicable).

    • Enter the Public IP address for the site and click Save to close the text box.

    • User count -- Select a range that represents the number of users at the site.

    • Traffic forwarding type – Select IPSec or Native endpoint steering (PAC, Agent).

    • FQDN -- Enter the Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) for the site. The FQDN maps to the Public IP address and provides a unique identifier for the site.

    • Private IP or subnet -- Identifies the source IP for the end user network through which the traffic is moving and helps to identify the correct tunnel to which traffic needs to be directed. For example, one site might use a desktop network while a second site might use a different subnet network. Sites can have the same or different subnets.

  3. Click Next.



  4. Enter the following encryption details.

    • Authentication method -- Select either Pre-Shared Key or Certificate.

      • A pre-shared key is shared between two endpoints. The keys on both endpoints must match for authentication to be successful.

      • A pre-shared key can be generated automatically by clicking the icon to the right of the Pre- Shared Key field. This generated key is longer, more complex, and provides stronger security than a pre-shared key you create and enter yourself.

      • If you enter a pre-shared key, the key should be between 8 and 64 characters long and include at least one lowercase character, one uppercase character, one numeric character, and one special character (for example, @ or %).

      • A certificate includes any certificate you have uploaded to Lookout SSE using Certificate Management. Select a certificate from the dropdown list. The selected certificate is presented for authentication. For information about creating and managing certificates, see Certificate Management.

    • IKE (Internet Key Exchange) -- IKE patterns are needed to establish tunnels. Lookout uses the IKEV2 protocol.

    • FIPS Compliant -- Check the toggle to ensure that all IKE and IPsec cipher sites are FIPS compliant.

    • Encryption Algorithm -- Select from the list of available cipher sites. If you have enabled FIPS compliance, the list is narrowed to include only the compliant security options.

    • Diffie-Hellman Group -- Select a value from the list. The higher the number in the value, the stronger the security. If you enabled FIPS compliance, this list is narrowed to include only the compliant security options.

    • Life Time -- Enter the number of hours (between 10 and 72) for the IKE lifetime. The IKE expires after this number of hours. For example, if you entered 20 hours, the IKE expires after 20 hours. Before it expires, the tunnel goes through a renegotiation process.

    • Click Next to configure advanced options.



  5. Under Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP), enter or select the following values.

    • Integrity and Encrypt algorithm -- Select a cipher site from the list.

    • ReKey -- Click the toggle to enable this option, which instructs Lookout to re-key the tunnel before the existing tunnel expires. The re-key process starts and the tunnel is re-negotiated. If this option is disabled, the tunnel is deactivated upon expiration and traffic cannot move through it.

    • ReAuth – Click the toggle to re-authenticates the two endpoints. This option is a recommended best practice to strengthen protection if either or both endpoints are changed or if the site has been compromised.

    • Depending on the authentication method you selected for the site, you can revoke access to the tunnel in two ways:

      • If you are using pre-shared keys, they will no longer match after they are changed when

        Reauth is enabled, and a compromised site connect with Lookout.

      • If you are using a certificate, you can remove or change the certificate.

    • Life Time -- Defines the lifetime of the tunnel itself. The tunnel life expires after the number of hours you enter. The value must be between 2 and 72 hours. This lifetime has a smaller minimum value (2 hours as opposed to 10 hours for the IKE lifetime) to enable a quicker end to a tunnel life, thus helping to prevent a tunnel from being compromised.

    • Dead peer detection -- Serves as a monitor of traffic "heartbeat," to detect the absence of traffic on a tunnel. The options for DPD action are:

      • None (default) -- Disables sending of active DPD messages.

      • Clear -- Closes the connection; no further action is taken.

      • Hold -- Installs a trap policy, which catches matching traffic and tries to re-negotiate the connection on demand.

      • Restart -- Triggers an attempt to re-negotiate the connection.

    • IKE Fragmentation -- A key exchange might include a large amount of data per packet. For example, a data packet might be larger than the Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU), which is the largest size frame or packet (approximately 1500 bytes for Ethernet links) that can be transmitted across a data link. Fragmentation allows the packet to be broken down into subpackets for transmission through the tunnel. Both endpoints must support fragmentation.

      The options are:

      • Yes (allow fragmentation)

      • Accept (if fragmenting occurs on the Lookout side, the other endpoint will accept it)

      • Force (if the packet size is known to be larger than the MTU, force fragmentation)

      • No (do not allow fragmentation).

  6. Click Save. The new site definition is added to the list on the Enterprise Sites page.

    A popup window displays tunnel configuration information, including Primary DNS and Secondary DNS information defined for the site. You can configure a tunnel for both a primary and a secondary DNS. The secondary DNS can serve as a backup to keep traffic moving if the primary tunnel goes down.



    • The Status field shows Disconnected or Connected status.

    • If the primary tunnel is connected, the status is displayed as connected.

Once tunnels are defined, you can set up and configure web and application policies in the Management Console to determine the appropriate actions for traffic moving through the tunnel.


High Availability support‌

Lookout SSE supports both Active/Standby and Active/Active high availability topologies with enterprise sites. Enterprise administrators can establish two IPsec VPN tunnels over each Wide Area Network (WAN) link to the primary and secondary Lookout SSE points of presence (POPs). These tunnels operate in an Active/Standby mode. Traffic is first forwarded over the Active tunnel to the primary POP. If the Active tunnel is terminated for some reason, the Standby tunnel can forward traffic to the secondary POP.

Enterprise sites having multiple WAN links can establish tunnels from each WAN to the primary and secondary Lookout SSE POPs. All tunnels to the primary SSE POP can operate in an Active/Active mode. Lookout SSE will forward the return traffic over the same tunnel it received from the enterprise site.


Configuring known locations‌

If traffic is coming from a known location (a branch office), users do not need to provide a tenant identifier. If you are using Secure Internet Access in explicit proxy mode with multiple tenants, you can define the locations where the traffic will be forwarded in explicit proxy mode. The proxy then can map the traffic from a location to your organization and apply policies accordingly.

You can configure a given site for Explicit Proxy (PAC file) based deployment by selecting Explicit Proxy as a traffic forwarding type.


Configuring API clients‌

Secure Cloud Access provides inbound integrations with external services based on APIs. These APIs enable administrators to identify authentication information for users, execute queries on a variety of factors including violations, activities, event types, content, and user IDs. For example, through these APIs, you can find out about how many anomalies have occurred over the last 30 minutes, or how many occurrences of a specific event occurred within the last hour. You can poll continuously for this data or extract it once.

From the Management Console, you can add one or more clients and configure the appropriate permissions and actions for each.

The API Clients page shows the following information for each client:

  • Name – The name given to this client.

  • Client ID – the unique ID that was provided for this client.

  • Permissions – The permissions enabled for this client. The permissions you check are those that the client will be allowed to access. The listed options are Activity, Violation, Anomaly, Insights, and Profile

  • Service URL – The URL used to access this client.

  • Authorized IPs – The valid IP address or addresses that apply to this client.

  • Actions – The actions you can take for this client. Click the icon for the action you want to perform. Editing client information, displaying the client secret, or deleting the client.

To add a new API client:

  1. Go to Administration > Enterprise Integration > API Clients and click New.

  2. Enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional).

  3. Enter the Client ID that was provided to you.

  4. Select one or more Permissions from the dropdown list.

  5. Enter one or more Authorized IP addresses for this client. Separate each address with a comma.

  6. Click Save.

  7. When prompted, copy the string for the client secret. You will need this information (along with the client ID) to authenticate to the API gateway.

Working with AnyApp™ connectors     ‌

The AnyApp™ Connector page lists all connectors (applications) currently installed in your organization, and shows the information for each connector, including its type, version, build and minimum required platform, and applications (if any) created for the connector.

You can perform a new installation for a connector or add a custom application.


Installing a connector‌

  1. Go to Administration > AnyApp™ Connectors.

  2. On the AnyApp™ Connector page, click Install New.

  3. Click Browse to find the .jar file for the connector you want to install.

  4. Select the .jar file to upload.

  5. Verify that this is the desired version of the connector you want to install.

  6. Click Install. The connector will be added to the list.


Adding a custom application as a connector‌

  1. On the AnyApp™ Connector page, click + New.

  2. Enter the following information:


    Field

    Description

    Connector Name

    Enter a name for the connector.

    Connector Version

    Enter the currently available version of the application.

    Description (optional)

    Enter a description.

    Protection Services

    Check ENCRYPTION or TOKENIZATION, or check Select All. Then click Save.

    Logo (optional)

    Upload a logo that identifies the connector. This logo will appear on the AnyApp™ Connectors page. The file size for the logo should be no larger than 50KB.

  3. From this point, you can configure the application as follows:

    • Advanced Function – Configure additional features for the application.

    • Application Resolution – Specify domains, cookies, and custom indicators for the application.

    • Encryption – Apply schemes to assign protection to sensitive data. You can select fields and assign compatible data protection schemes using the selection lists and retrieve schema information from the cloud.

    • Parser – Upload parser transaction files for SOAP or REST inbound and outbound web service calls. These files specify the logic to identify sensitive field content.

  4. After you have completed the appropriate configurations, click Summary to display a summary of the settings, and confirm the addition of the application.

    Setting up and managing environments   ‌

    Every environment you create initially uses the system settings service configurations you applied during initial configuration (and may have updated). You might need to customize those settings with different values for different environments. You can customize service and logging configurations for each environment you create. For example, you might need to add an upstream proxy, change domain names and certificates, or change the logging settings, for an environment.

    In hosted (cloud) environments, some values are automatically overridden, and you cannot disable those overrides. For on-premise environments, overrides are enabled, which allows you to change settings for the services you use. It is recommended that you view the settings for the services you plan to use for any on-premise environment you create and configure them as needed.

    The Environment Management page stores all information about existing environments. From this page, you can customize (override) the settings for on-premise environments, perform debugging, and duplicate or remove an environment.

    The Environment Management page shows the following information for each environment. Use the Column Filter at the upper right to show or hide columns.


    • Environment Name -- The name of the environment.

    • Assigned Nodes -- The number of nodes currently assigned to the environment. To view the names and versions of the node or nodes, hover over the number hyperlink.

    • Environment Type -- The selected type for the environment: Cloud, On-premise Connector, or On- premise Gateway Server.

    • Services -- The services enabled on nodes associated with the environment.

      • For On-premise Connector types: Log Agent, SIEM Agent, or EDLP Agent.

      • For On-premise Gateway Server types: Proxy, DPaaS, or Email.

    • Created on -- The date on which the environment was created.

    • Modified on -- The date (if any) on which the environment was last modified.

    • Modified by -- The email address of the user who last modified the environment.

    • Version -- The current version for environments with assigned nodes. An up arrow in a circle indicates that a newer version is available. Hover over the icon to view the available version. If no nodes have been assigned, NODE_NOT_ASSIGNED appears here.

    • Actions – You can perform the following actions:

      • Debug -- Analyze issues pertaining to the nodes of the environment through configuring and retrieving various types of logs.

      • Copy (duplicate) and environment.

      • Remove an environment.


Viewing and editing environment details‌

To view the details for an environment:

Click the down arrow to the left of the environment name.

The environment name, description (if any), and any other custom settings are displayed. The following example shows an environment type of Cloud.



The following example shows an environment type of On-Premise Connector.



The following example shows an environment type of On-Premise Gateway Server.


Creating a new environment‌

  1. Go to Administration > Environment Management and click New.

  2. Enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional).

  3. Select the environment Type. The options are Cloud, On-Premise Gateway Server, and On- Premise Connector.

  4. If you selected On-premise Gateway Server or On-premise Connector, enter one or more valid IPv4 addresses for the connection. If you enter multiple IP addresses, separate each address with a comma.



    Note When a node connects to the Node Manager, the Node Manager validates the node's IP address against what is configured in the environment. If an on-premise node connects, the Node Manager will see the node's public IP address, not the private IP address. As a result, the IP address for the node needs to be public.

    To determine the public IP address for the connector machine, run this command:

    curl https://ifconfig.me/

  5. Click Next.

  6. In the Connector Settings page, select the TLS settings and services for the environment.



  7. For TLS Settings, check the protocols and cipher cites to apply to this environment.

  8. For services, click the toggles to enable the services to apply to this environment.

    • ZTNA – Enabled when you click the toggle.

    • Log Agent – Select the log agent from the dropdown list. This list includes the log agents you created previously.



    • SIEM Agent – Select a SIEM agent from the dropdown list. This list includes the SIEM agents you created previously.



      To enable an upstream proxy for the SIEM agent, select a proxy from the dropdown list. This list includes the upstream proxies you created previously. If you do not need to use an upstream proxy, accept the default value of None.

      Note If you want to use an upstream proxy for this environment, enable only the SIEM service for it. Do not enable the other services. Upstream proxy is supported only for SIEM services.

    • EDLP Agent – Select an EDLP agent from the dropdown list. This list includes the EDLP agents you created previously.



  9. Click Next.


  10. (Optional) To update the default log configuration settings, click the Override Log Configuration toggle. The default settings are displayed. If you do not want to update these settings now, click Save. You can update them at any time after you create the environment.



    Enter or select the log settings as follows:

    • Log Level -- Warn, Info (default), Debug, or Trace.

    • Number of Log Files -- Enter the maximum number of log files to include for debugging.

    • Log File Max Size -- Enter the maximum size (in MB) for each log file.

  11. Click Save to save the environment. You can now assign nodes to it.

Customizing (overriding) settings for an environment‌

You can edit the settings for an environment in any order.

Note The new settings you enter for an environment override the default system settings only for that environment. The default global settings are not changed. Furthermore, changes in the global settings will not modify the environment-level override settings. For convenience, the initial settings are the current global settings, but once saved they are maintained independently.

  1. Click the icon for the service whose settings you want to override or click Next until you get to the settings you want to edit.

  2. Click the Override toggle button. The system settings for that service are displayed.

  3. Make the needed changes.

  4. Click Save.

To switch back to using global settings for a service in an on-premise environment, toggle the Override button to the off state and save the environment. The environment will “remember” the override configuration, and you can later switch back to it later by toggling the Override button to on


Debugging nodes‌

Debugging can be limited to specific nodes or services (with Communication as the agent). In addition, you can add the names of packages and specific classes, each with their own log levels, to get exactly the logging details needed to diagnose a problem. The details associated with the use of packages will typically be supplied by support services, based on the nature of the problem.

When live debugging is disabled, the nodes return to normal logging.

The Debug option in the Actions column of the Management Console allows you to perform analysis and troubleshooting for nodes in an environment.



The options include:

  • Log Download -- Allows you to retrieve and download generated log files from nodes.

  • Debugging Settings -- Allows you to temporarily override logging settings, such as log file size and quantity, and log levels for selected services on selected nodes.

  • HAR Logging -- Allows generation of HTTP Archive (HAR) files to analyze network requests flowing through data proxies on selected nodes.

  • Watchdog Settings – Allows you to set restart thresholds (in minutes) for the assigned nodes, based on memory and CPU utilization.

    The following options are available for each environment type:


    Cloud

    On-premise Connector


    Note: All the above options are applicable for Secure Private Access.

    On-premise Gateway Server

    • Log Download

    • Debugging

    • HAR Logging

    • Log Download

    • Watchdog Settings

    • Debugging Settings

    • Har Logging

    • Log Download

    • Debugging Settings

    • HAR Logging

    • Watchdog Settings

    The following sections outline the configuration steps for these options. Click the Debug icon for the environment you want to configure.


    Log Download‌

    Click the Log Download tab if it is not already displayed.


    Enter the following information:


    Field

    Description

    Select Node(s)

    Select the nodes in this environment to be included in the log download. Each will produce one file.

    Log File Prefix

    Enter a prefix to identify the log files (for example, PRI-2345).

    Services

    Select one or more services for the environment type.

    Cloud – Communication, Proxy, Email, DPaaS

    On-premise Connector – Communication, ZTNA Connector, SIEM Agent, EDLP Agent

    On-premise Gateway Server – Communication, Proxy, Email, DPaaS

    Log File Password

    Enter a password to be used to protect (encrypt) the ZIP file in which the log files will be packaged.

    Log Start Time

    Select a time at which the logging started. All log files with updates from that time to the present will be included.

    Click Retrieve Log Files.

    Immediately, an entry will be added into the table whose status will be Retrieving or Failed. When the status changes to Complete, the file is ready to download through the browser.



    Each node will send a single password-protected ZIP file to the Management Server. The file name begins with the specified prefix and then adds the node name and the time range. Clicking the Log File link will store the file in the browser’s Download directory.

    Use a third-party tool that supports passwords to extract the log files.

    In addition to downloading the log files, two icons are available in the Action column:

  • Delete -- Delete a file.

  • View -- View the password for the file.



Debugging settings‌

This section describes how the system allows fine-grained control of log settings for specific services on nodes. The values set here will override the global settings specified under System Settings > Log Configuration > Node Server and environment-specific settings on the Log Configuration tab until Live Debugging is disabled.


To configure debugging settings, click the Live Debugging Enable toggle and enter or select the following settings.


Field

Description

Node Name

Select the nodes in this environment to be included in the log download. Each will produce one file.

Global Log Level

Select a log level – Warn, Info, Debug, or Trace.


Adding packages‌

You can add logging packages, each with their own log levels, to address specific system problems. You will most likely use this feature in collaboration with your services team.

To add a logging package:

  1. Click Add Package.

  2. Enter a dot-separated name for the package.

  3. Select the log level for this package.

  4. Click Add.

  5. When you have completed all debugging configuration, click Save.


HAR logging‌

HAR logging can be configured for Cloud environment types.

HAR logging enables generation of HTTP Archive (HAR) logs, which show information regarding network requests generated in a browser when an issue occurs. HAR logs can provide valuable information such as how long an object takes to be requested, the time required to connect to the server, and the time taken to transfer items from the server to the browser, as well as actions by privileged users. A HAR log can help you detect problems such as excessively long load times, no loading activity, or no caching taking place.


Generated HAR logs are in JSON format.

IMPORTANT

HAR logging is done in memory for security purposes. Sensitive information such as passwords are typically included, so HAR logging must be used with care.

To start HAR logging:

  1. Click the Live Debugging Enable toggle.

  2. Enter the following information.


    Field

    Description

    Select Node(s)

    From the list, select the nodes to be included in the HAR log.

    Log File Prefix

    Enter a log file prefix to help identify the HAR file.

    Log File Password

    Enter a password for accessing the HAR log. This password is used to encrypt the zip file and will be required for extracting the file.

    Log File Max Size

    Enter the maximum file size for the HAR log or accept the default size of 10MB.

  3. Click the Start HAR Log button. The button name will change to Stop HAR Log and the icon to a red circle containing a white square.

  4. Run tests.

  5. Click the Stop HAR Log button again to stop the log. If you do not stop the log, it will run until the specified Log File Max Size is reached.

Generated HAR logs are listed at the bottom of the Debugging page. The list includes the following information about each HAR log:


Field

Description

Node Name

The name(s) of the node(s) included in the log.

Log File

The system-generated name of the HAR log file. (*.har)

Start Time

The day and time that HAR logging starts.

End Time

The day and time that HAR logging ends.

Status

The progress of the HAR log (for example, in progress or completed).

Password

The debugging password you created in the Log File Password field.

Action

Any actions indicated by the logging process.

Because of the large file sizes that are often generated, HAR logging could have an impact on system performance. HAR logging should be done only for short periods of time when an activity of interest is in progress. It is recommended that you work with Support when running HAR logging.


Watchdog Settings‌

Watchdog settings can be configured for On-premise Connector and Web Gateway Server

environments.



Click the Watchdog Settings tab, click the Enable Watchdog toggle, and enter or select the following options.


Field

Description

Select Node(s)

Select the nodes to include for watchdog settings or select All Nodes.

Restart on CPU Utilization

Check the box to enable the threshold setting for restarting. Then enter a threshold value and time in minutes.

Restart on Memory Utilization

Check the box to enable the threshold setting for restarting. Then enter a threshold value and time in minutes.

Click Save.


Duplicating or removing an environment‌

Duplicating (cloning) an environment can be useful for testing purposes (for example, if your QA team needs to determine the best settings for an environment).

You can remove an environment if it is no longer needed (for example, if you have a test environment that is no longer used). You cannot delete an environment that currently includes one or more nodes; you must delete the nodes or assign them to different environments (or None) to enable deletion.

Setting up and managing nodes       ‌

From the Node Management page, you can define nodes, specify which services they should run, assign nodes to environments, view security tokens, remove nodes and start or stop services. You can also view system usage metrics for the node’s host and services.

The following section provides information about node management in both hosted and on-premise deployments.

To view a list of nodes, go to Administration > Node Management. Use the Column Filter at the upper right to show or hide columns in the list.

For hosted deployments:


Field

Description

Node Name

The name given to the node when it was installed.

Node Type

The selected node type – either Connector or Gateway Server.

IP

The IP address of the node when it was last connected to the Management Server.

State

The current activity state of the node.

  • Active --The node is assigned to an environment and has the latest configuration.

  • Outdated -- The node is assigned to an environment, but the configuration it is using does not reflect the latest values in the Management Server. You can update the node from the Management Console. See Upgrading the Node Server from the Management Console.

  • Inactive -- The node is not assigned to any environment.

Health

The condition of the node and its services. For example:

  • OK -- All services are running.

  • Starting -- One or more services is starting.

  • Stopped -- One or more services has stopped.

  • Disconnected -- The agent is disconnected from the Management Server.

  • Never seen -- The node has never connected to the Management Server. You can keep the node if it will be used in the future or delete it if it is no longer needed.

The value shown reflects the lowest health state of any service for that node. For example, if two services are running but one is stopped, the health status is shown as Stopped.

Environment

The environment to which the node is assigned. Every node needs to be associated with an environment.

Services

The services enabled on this node. Hover over any service name to see the status of each service on the node.

AnyApp Connectors Used

The names of the connectors with applications on the node.

Node Version

The current version of the node.

Installed On

The date on which the node was last installed.

Modified On

The date on which the node information was last modified.

CPU

The CPU usage for the node, by percentage.

Memory

The memory usage for the node, by percentage.


Field

Description

Actions

The actions that can be performed on a node. See Stopping or Restarting Services.

For on-premise deployments:

The Node Management page lists each node that has been defined, showing the following information:


Field

Description

Node Name

The name given to the node when it was installed.

IP

The IP address of the node when it was last connected to the Management Server.

State

The current activity state of the node.

  • Active --The node is assigned to an environment and has the latest configuration.

  • Outdated -- The node is assigned to an environment, but the configuration it is using does not reflect the latest values in the Management Server. You can update the node from the Management Console. See Upgrading the Node Server from the Management Console.

  • Inactive -- The node is not assigned to any environment.

Health

The condition of the node and its services. For example:

  • OK -- All services are running.

  • Starting -- One or more services is starting.

  • Stopped -- One or more services has stopped.

  • Disconnected -- The agent is disconnected from the Management Server.

  • Never seen -- The node has never connected to the Management Server. You can keep the node if it will be used in the future or delete it if it is no longer needed.

The value shown reflects the lowest health state of any service for that node. For example, if two services are running but one is stopped, the health status is shown as

Stopped.

Environment

The environment to which the node is assigned. Every node needs to be associated with an environment.

Services

The services enabled on this node. Hover over any service name to see the status of each service on the node.

AnyApp Connectors

Used

The names of the connectors with applications on the node.

Node Version

The current version of the node.

Installed On

The date on which the node was last installed.

Modified On

The date on which the node information was last modified.

CPU

The CPU usage for the node, by percentage.

Memory

The memory usage for the node, by percentage.

Actions

The actions that can be performed on a node. See Stopping or Restarting Services.

Click the > button next to a node to view its details.


The following sections provide details about metrics, configuration, modifying node information, working with services, and upgrading nodes for hosted and on-premise deployments.


Node metrics‌

Note For Gateway Server type nodes with hosted environments (Cloud environment type), the

Overview tab with node metrics does not appear.

For Connector and On-Premise Gateway Server node types, the Overview tab displays information about node metrics, which can provide valuable information about how a node is using resources. This information can help to identify possible performance issues or anomalies.

The top of the page shows current summary metrics for CPU, memory, and disk utilization, as well as the current thread count and the number of services used with the node, along with how many of those services are currently running. For example, 3/3 indicates three services, all of which are currently running.

The Overview tab also shows line graphs that provide details for each resource category. Each line represents the metrics for a service. The horizontal axis indicates the time; the vertical axis indicates percentage of the resource utilized. The Total line represents total usage on the host machine; it is not limited to only Lookout processes.



You can select a time range for the data to view – for the last hour, last 4 hours, or last 24 hours.

At the upper right, average, minimum and maximum percentages are displayed for the Total line for the specified period.


You can use the Showing Range dropdown list to show metrics for the last hour (default selection), last four hours, or last 24 hours. In addition, you can filter out the Total or particular service metrics by clicking any of the names in the legend (for example, Email). The service name will be dimmed and the line graph hidden. To resume the view, click the service name again.

You can view a specific numeric value with its exact time by hovering over a point in any line graph. You can also zoom in on a time range with the left mouse button. Click the Reset zoom button to return to the complete time range.



Node configuration information‌

The Configuration tab displays the current configuration details for the node. Other than the name and node type, all of the information can be modified at any time. When saving, the node’s configuration will be updated automatically if the node is connected. Otherwise, the new configuration will be sent the next time the node starts and registers with the Management Server.


If the ZTNA Connector service is used for the node, the Mutual Auth Client Certificate field also appears, with the selected certificate.

By default, the node API token is not displayed; for security it is not even retrieved. Clicking the Show API Token button retrieves the API token and puts it into a text box from which you can copy it. You can then paste it during node installation.


Creating a node‌

  1. Go to Administration > Node Management and click New.

  2. Enter a Node Name (required) and a Description (optional).

  3. Select a Node Type. The options are

    • Connector

    • Gateway Server

  4. Select an Environment from the dropdown list. A node must be associated with an environment.

  5. Check the Services to apply to this node.

    • If you selected Gateway Server as the node type, the options are Proxy, Email Gateway, and

      DPaaS.

    • If you selected Connector as the node type, the options are Log Agent, SIEM Agent, and EDLP Agent.

  6. Click Add Node.

    A confirmation message is displayed with the token created for the node.



  7. Click Copy to Clipboard to copy the token ID to your clipboard.

The new node is added to the Node Management page, with an initial state of Inactive and a health status of Never Seen.


Modifying node information‌

To modify node information:

  1. Click the Configuration tab.

  2. Modify the information for the node as needed.

  3. Click Update to save the changes.


Stopping or restarting services‌

In some situations, you might need a node to be defined and accessible to administrators, but not running any of its services. To do so, click the down arrow on the far right of the node table to display a menu of actions.


Field

Description

Start Services

Activate all enabled services.

Stop Services

Bring down all services. The node is available, but not doing anything other than reporting host metrics.


Field

Description

Restart Services

Stop and then restart all services after retrieving updated configurations.

Remove Node

Removes the selected node.


Removing a node‌

Once you have stopped the Node Server from the command line, you can remove a node.

  1. Go to Administration > Node Management.

  2. On the Node Management page, select the node you want to remove.

  3. Click the down arrow at the far right.

  4. From the menu, click Remove Node. The Remove Node selection indicates to the Management Server that the node will not be coming back.

  5. When prompted, confirm deletion of the node.


Upgrading the Node Server from the Management Console (hosted)‌

To obtain an upgrade package for the Node Server:

  1. Go to Administration > System Settings.

  2. Under Software, click Downloads.

  3. To upgrade, select Node Server Tar Package, and click the Download icon.

  4. Save the package file.

  5. To display information about a download file or package (such as version and file size), click the information icon.

Configuring and managing certificates    ‌

Certificate information is used in several types of configurations throughout the system and is required in order for those configurations to work. The gateway needs a certificate for data proxy and browser interactions with the Management Console.

Certificate management for cloud deployments will be handled by Lookout. You can configure additional certificates for on-premise use or for integration with third-party systems as needed.

The following sections describe the types of certificates available for use, and instructions for importing or generating additional certificates if needed.


Types of certificates‌

The Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol is commonly used to encrypt information sent across the Internet. Secure server certificates allow web servers to establish TLS sessions with browsers.

You can either import a valid CA signed certificate or generate a new certificate. Generated certificates are intended for use only in test environments.

The following certificate types are available for configuration in the Certificate Management page:

  • Client/Server certificates -- These are TLS server certificates that are required for configuration and validation of the Management Console, Reverse Proxy, DPaaS settings, email gateway, and application-specific web services.

  • Signing CA certificates -- Signing CA certificates are essential in configuring forward proxy settings. Each entry represents a certificate and private key, along with a certificate chain required when validating the signature on the certificate. Signing CA certificates are valid for one year.

  • Trusted CAS -- Trusted CA certificates are those for which the Add to Trusted CAs checkbox is selected during certificate import or generation are displayed in this tab. Additionally, CA certificates can be imported. These certificates are added to the truststore for all node services. If the Use Default Java Truststore Certificates flag is checked, these are used in addition to those in the truststore included in the java installation on the node’s host; otherwise, they are used instead of the java truststore.

  • Intermediary CAS -- These certificates are part of a chain that is presented by a web site and secured by TLS. The entries here are used along with those in Trusted CAs in cases where a server does not present a complete certificate chain during the TLS connection handshake.

  • Identity certificates -- These certificates are needed for Single Sign-On (SSO). An identity certificate validates the assertion from the identity provider (IDP) and must be provided when SSO rewriting is done.


Importing a TLS certificate‌

To import a valid CA signed TLS certificate:

  1. Go to Administration > Certificate Management.

  2. Click Import. The browser’s file chooser appears.

  3. Browse and select a certificate.

    Notes

    • The file selected must be either a Java KeyStore (.jks) or PKCS#12 (.pfx or .p12) file.

    • It is expected that the file will contain only one entry with a private key. If there are multiple entries, only the first entry encountered when loading the file will be used.

  4. Click Open. The system prompts you to enter passwords for the certificate.

  5. Enter the Key Password and Keystore Password. The Key Password was used to protect (encrypt) the private key. The Keystore Password is used to ensure the integrity of the entire Keystore. Enter the values that were used when generating the Keystore.



    By default, the Add to Trusted CAs checkbox is selected. Keep this box checked. If it is not checked, the certificate will not be treated as a trusted certificate and will not be displayed under the Trusted CAs tab.

  6. Click Save. A confirmation message is displayed.


Generating a new certificate‌

To generate a certificate:

  1. Go to Administration > Certificate Management.

  2. Click Generate.



  3. Enter the following information (all fields must be filled in):


    Field

    Description

    Key Password

    This password protects (encrypts) the private key. Enter a value that conforms to the requirements.

    Confirm Key Password

    Re-enter the key password.

    Keystore Password

    This password ensures the integrity of the entire KeyStore. Enter a value that conforms to the requirements.

    Confirm Keystore Password

    Re-enter the Keystore password.

    Common Name

    Enter the Common Name (CN) that identifies the fully qualified domain name(s) associated with the certificate. This is critical for TLS certificates. *.name is a wildcard certificate. CN values must be unique within a tab.

    Organization Unit

    Enter the business unit in the organization generating the certificate.

    Organization

    Enter the organization generating the certificate.

    Country

    Enter the country from which the certificate is generated.

    Validity

    Select the validity period for the certificate. The default is two (2) years. You can specify the validity for one to three years.


    The Add to Trusted CAs checkbox is selected by default. If this box is not checked, the certificate will not be treated as a trusted certificate and will not be displayed under the Trusted CAs tab.

  4. Click Save and Add Certificate. A confirmation message is displayed.

The certificate is added to the list of available certificates in the Management Console.


Viewing certificate details‌

To view details for a certificate:

  1. Go to Administration > Certificate Management.

  2. Under the Action column, click the icon.


  3. Click the Pem Certificate link available on the top right corner to view the certificate details in PEM format.



  4. To enable a browser to validate and accept the certificate details, click Copy to clipboard.

  5. Paste the copied content into a text file on the local machine and save it with a .cert extension.

  6. Import this file into the browser to enable the browser to accept the certificate.


Deleting a certificate‌

You can delete a certificate if it is no longer needed, but only when it is not currently being used by any configuration. If you try to delete a certificate that is in use, you will be notified of which configuration is still using it.

To delete a certificate:

  1. Go to Administration > Certificate Management. The Certificate Management page is displayed.

  2. Under the Action column, click the delete icon to delete the certificate. The system prompts you to confirm the deletion of the selected certificate.



  3. Click Yes to delete the certificate. The system deletes the selected certificate from the system and displays a message on successful deletion.

Configuring   data   proxy   settings       ‌

To protect data flowing between browsers and the cloud service, configure proxy settings in the Management Console for a Cloud environment type.

To configure data proxy settings for hosted or on-premise deployments:

  1. Go to Administration > Environment Management.

  2. Select the Cloud environment for which you want to configure data proxy settings.

  3. Click the Data Proxy icon.

  4. Configure the settings as follows:

    Click the Data Proxy toggle button to enable the data proxy. Then, configure settings as follows.

    • Forward and reverse proxy settings

    • Intercept SAML

    • Upstream proxy (on-premise)

    • TLS settings

    • Incoming request settings

    • File extension and size (on-premise)


Forward and reverse proxy settings‌

Configure forward and reverse proxy settings as follows.


Forward proxy‌

Perform the steps in the following sections to configure the forward proxy and verify traffic flow.


Defining enterprise locations

As part of forward proxy configuration, Lookout recommends that you define the sites in your organization (for example, your corporate headquarters and any branch offices) from which traffic will be routed. When you create an enterprise site, you need to specify its location, provide a unique public IP address, and select the type of traffic forwarding for that site (either IPSec or Native Client Steering).

For information and instructions for creating and managing enterprise sites, see Creating and managing enterprise sites.


Uploading a certificate

  1. Click the toggle to enable forward proxy settings.

  2. Go to Administration > Certificate Management.

  3. On the Certificate Management page, specify the CA certificate either by uploading an existing signing CA certificate or by generating a signing CA certificate. The forward proxy generates the certificate(s) for the requested domain using the configured Signing CA Certificate. The validity of the certificate is one year.

Updating forward proxy settings

  1. Enter or select the following information:

    • CA Certificate -- Select a certificate from the dropdown list.

    • Proxy Address -- Enter the fully qualified domain name of the tenant to which forward proxy routing applies.

    • Exclude Domains – Enter the names of the domains to exclude from forward proxy routing.

      Note for MacOS domains

      Because Apple upgrades do not work with proxy routing, you must add the following domains to the Exclude Domains list to bypass the proxy and enable MacOS upgrades:

      • apple.com

      • icloud.com

      • mzstatic.com

        • Exclude IP Addresses – Enter the IP addresses to exclude from forward proxy routing.

          Note for excluding domains and IP addresses

          If you have upgraded to this release from a previous release, you must delete any existing invalid domains and IP addresses manually.

          To do so:

          • Go to the Management Console and select Administration > Environment Management.

          • In the Exclude Domains and Exclude IP Addresses fields, delete any invalid domains or IP addresses.


          • Save your changes.

        • Https Proxy Certificate – If you are applying HTTPS configuration, Select an applicable certificate.

  2. Click Save to save these values.


Importing a certificate to the user device

  1. Go to Administration > Certificate Management.

  2. Click the Trusted CAs tab.

  3. Download the certificate and save it in .cer format.

  4. Import the root CA certificate to the certificate management area on the user device.

    • For Windows devices, import the certificate into the user Certificate store (certmgr.msc).

    • For Mac devices, use the Keychain login.


Selecting a PAC file

  1. Go to Home > Secure Cloud Workspace.

  2. Click the PAC file icon at the upper right.


  3. Hover over the PAC file to apply to your system configuration and click its link.

  4. Configure the selected PAC file on the user device to route the traffic to the Lookout forward proxy. For more information about PAC files, see Working with PAC files in the Secure Cloud Workspace.

Verifying traffic flow in forward proxy mode

  1. Open a private browser.

  2. Launch an application onboarded for inline mode.

  3. You will be prompted to authenticate with proxy authentication. See the next section, Configuring Proxy Authentication.

  4. Check for the presence of the certificate, as shown in the following example.



    Configuring proxy authentication

    Go to Administration > System Settings > Enterprise Authentication to configure proxy authentication.

    You can select either active or passive authentication.

    • Active authentication is for Lookout proxy authentication. User information is applied based on the SSO login (proxy authentication) credentials.

    • Passive authentication is for a downstream authenticating proxy (such as BlueCoat) authentication. User login information is applied based on the cloud login credentials, if the header does not contain the user information.

  1. Select a Proxy Authentication Method, either Enterprise Single Sign-on (active) or Proxy Header Authentication (passive).

    If you select Proxy Header Authentication:

    • Enter an Authentication Header name.

    • Enter a Tenant Header Name for the applicable tenant.

  2. Click Save.

    Note When forward proxy is used for SSO-enabled cloud applications, create a Cloud Authentication policy with the Allow & Go Direct action, which will enable traffic to be sent to the cloud via a direct URL rather than a hyphenated URL after SSO authentication.


    Reverse proxy‌

    Click the toggle to enable reverse proxy settings and enter the following information.


    • Domain name – Enter a fully-qualified domain name to apply to the reverse proxy.

    • Certificate – Select a certificate from the dropdown list.


Intercept SAML‌

(Security Assertion Markup Language)

Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) is an XML-based format that enables authentication and authorization between an identity provider and a service provider.

Click the toggle to enable Intercept SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language) for Single Sign On (SSO) configurations.

IMPORTANT You must enable your client to use Server Name Indication (SNI) to connect with the Lookout gateway.

Enter the following information.



  1. Click +Add IdP and enter one or more IdP entity IDs. An IdP ID specifies the identity provider (also known as the Identity Assertion Validator). The identity provider can assert to the system with which the user is trying to interact that the identifier is known to the provider. The system can then validate the IdP assertion. You can enter up to 10 IdP entity IDs. For example, if you have three IdP servers, you can enter a separate IdP ID for each. Each IdP ID you add is listed in the table below the SAML Signing Certificate field.



    You can use the icons in the Action column at the right to edit information about each IdP ID or remove an IdP certificate you no longer need.

  2. Select an IdP validation certificate. This is the certificate to be used to validate the SAML assertion presented by the IdP. The proxy will use this certificate to make sure the original assertion is authentic before rewriting it. If you see the message No Certificates Found, click the Please upload Identity Certificate link, which will take you to the Certificate Management page. From there, you can import an identity certificate. For instructions, see Configuring and managing certificates.

  3. Select an SAML Signing certificate from the list. The proxy uses this to re-sign the SAML assertion after rewriting. To enter additional IdP IDs, click +Add IdP.


Upstream Proxy‌

You can configure an upstream proxy and select the option for proxy authentication.

  1. Go to Administration > System Settings and select Upstream Proxy.

  2. Click New.

  3. Enter the following information.

    • Description – Enter a brief description for this upstream proxy configuration.

    • Host – Enter the host provided by your network administrators.

    • Port –The port number for this configuration. Enter the port number provided by your network administrator.

    • (Optional) To enable proxy authentication, check Proxy Authentication. In the fields that appear, enter the user name and password for authentication.

    • User Name – Enter the valid user name for the user to which this configuration applies.

    • Password – Enter a password for this user.

    • Note: Only basic authentication is supported for upstream proxy.

  4. Click Save.


    TLS Settings‌


    • For Protocols, select one or more versions from the list, or select All Protocols.

    • For Cipher Suites, select one or more cipher suites from the list.


Incoming Request Settings‌


  1. Enter the IP addresses to allow. You can enter standard IP address formats, subnet masks, or IP ranges. Separate each entry with a comma.

  2. Click Save.


    File Extension and Size Settings‌

    Under File Extension and Size Settings, select exclusion settings for file types, MIME types, and file sizes. The items you select here will be excluded from scanning.

    These settings apply to on-premise deployments. For hosted deployments, file exclusion settings can be found in System Settings > Advanced Configuration.



    • For file types, review the default list of file extensions to be excluded. Add or delete files as needed. Files that you exclude are not processed by the gateway, so response time will be faster when you open and view them. For example, rich-media files such as .mov, .mp3, or .mp4 will load faster if they are excluded.

    • For MIME types, enter each MIME type to be excluded (for example, text/css or application/pdf. To exclude any video types, enter video/*.*. Separate each MIME type with a comma.

    • For file sizes, enter a file size (in megabytes) that will serve as the threshold for exclusion from scanning. Any files larger than this size will be excluded from scanning. You must enter a value greater than zero.

      When you have entered all data proxy configuration information, click Save. You will see a confirmation message.

      Configuring protocol support and DNS resolution options‌

      You can specify how the Lookout proxy should handle unsupported TLS, unsupported Port 80/443 protocols, and QUIC protocol. You can also enable or disable Domain Name System (DNS) resolution by the Lookout proxy when traffic is steered from non-PAC file deployment (for instance, traffic coming from an SD-WAN edge at a branch office location).

      Go to Administration > System Settings > Advanced Configuration and click the Policy Settings tab to configure protocol support and DNS resolution options.


      Protocol support options‌


      In the Protocol Support section, click the toggles to enable or disable the following options for each protocol support type.


      Bypass Unsupported TLS Protocols

      When this setting is enabled, requests to sites will not be inspected by the proxy. When this setting is disabled, these requests will be blocked.

    • Non-TLS traffic on Port 443

    • Do not support SNI

    • Use ESNI/ECH


      Bypass Unsupported Port 80/443 Protocols

      When this setting is enabled, requests to sites will not be inspected by the proxy. If this setting is disabled, these requests will be blocked.

    • Non-HTTP traffic

    • Unknown HTTP versions or methods

    • Unsupported HTTP content types


      Downgrade QUIC Protocol to HTTP/S

    • When this setting is enabled (recommended), QUIC traffic will be blocked. Most clients will revert to TLS 1.2, which will be inspected.

    • When this setting is disabled, QUIC traffic will be allowed and will not be inspected.

      DNS Resolution options‌

      This setting applies only to traffic coming from a site location or an endpoint. It does not apply to traffic from the explicit proxy (PAC file deployment).

    • When enabled, Lookout re-resolves the DNS address of the destination.

    • When disabled, Lookout uses the destination IP in the TCP request. Click Save to save all options.

      Configuring email gateway settings      ‌

      The Lookout email gateway monitors and processes email coming into and going out of a cloud application. You can enable the email gateway and select settings for a Cloud environment type through the Environment Management page of the Management Console.

    • For inbound mail, you can specify client IP addresses and acceptable domains.

    • For outbound mail, you can specify delivery options and acceptable outgoing domains and IP addresses.


Management Console configurations for email‌

Perform the following steps for Cloud environment types to configure email gateway settings.

  1. Go to Administration > Environment Management.

  2. Click the pen icon to the left of the environment for which you want to configure email gateway settings.

  3. Select the Email icon.

  4. (Optional) To validate the certificate while processing emails, click the Enable Client Auth toggle.

  5. Enter settings as described in the following sections.


Incoming emails from cloud applications or user‌

The Incoming and Outgoing pertain to the Postfix MTA and not the cloud. These settings control emails both from the cloud and from a user/Postfix to the cloud.

Note The email gateway requires access to a DPaaS service in the same environment. These settings apply to mail coming from external senders to the cloud application.

Field

Description

Allowed client IP addresses

Enter the IP addresses that will be trusted to communicate with the

Postfix server. This should include the corporate email system that is forwarding email to the email gateway.

Acceptable Domain Name/IP address

The customer and cloud domains for incoming mail that are trusted as valid addresses. Enter the domain names (for example, xyz.com), separated by commas. The gateway will process only the items you

enter here. If nothing is entered, then all machines will be allowed to send email to the cloud through the gateway.

Domain Name Certificate

For on-premise deployments and Management Server:

These values are pre-configured.


Outgoing email settings‌

These settings apply to mail communication from the Postfix SMTP server to the customer’s SMTP server or to external recipients.


Field

Description

Delivery options

The delivery option for transmitting outbound email, either Internet (MX) (default), or Internal Relay. For example, organizations with Microsoft Exchange servers would typically use Internal Relay.

If you choose Internal Relay, enter a domain name and port number.

Domain Name (Internal Relay)

Enter a domain name for the Internal Relay delivery option.

Port (Internal Relay)

Enter a port number for the Internal Relay delivery option.

Acceptable ongoing domains/IP

The domain names or IP addresses that are trusted as valid addresses for outgoing mail transmissions. The gateway will process only the items you enter here.

Enter the allowable domains or IP addresses, separated by commas.


Click Save.


Configuring Office 365 email routing‌

This section outlines the instructions for configuring email routing between Office 365 and the Lookout secure email gateway. This configuration includes the following procedures:

  • Creating and configuring an email flow rule in Exchange

  • Configuring a connector for routing email from Office 365 to the secure email gateway

  • Whitelisting the secure email gateway to Office 365

  • Configuring forwarding of email


Creating and configuring an email flow rule in Exchange‌

  1. Log in to your Office 365 account as a global admin user.

  2. Go to Admin center > Exchange.

  3. Click mail flow in the Exchange admin center.

  4. Go to Rules.



  5. Click Add New Rule.

  6. Configure the rule as shown in the following screens.



  7. Click Save.


Configuring a connector for routing email from Office 365 to the secure email gateway‌

  1. Go to Connectors.


  2. Click Add a connector.

  3. Select the From and To options as shown (Office 365 to Your organization’s email server).


  4. Click Next.

  5. Enter the Name you used in the procedure for creating the rule for the connector. Then, click Next.



  6. Select Only when I have a transport rule set up that redirects messages to this connector and click Next.

  7. To route email, enter the domain email-occ.ciphercloud.io and click Next. The domain details will be provided by the implementation team.

  8. Verify the setting and click Next.

  9. Click Next.

  10. Enter a valid email address to validate the connector configuration. Then, click Validate.

Allowlisting the Lookout secure email gateway to Office 365‌

  1. Go to Connectors and click Add New Connector.

  2. Enter the following information as shown:

    • From -- Your organization’s email server

    • To -- Office 365

  3. Click Next.

  4. Enter the connector Name and click Next.

  5. Select the second option button to enable allowlisting of the IP addresses. If necessary, contact Support to obtain the IP addresses that should be allowlisted.



  6. Click Next to verify the new connector details.

  7. Click Save.


Configuring forwarding of email‌

  1. Log on to the Lookout Management Console and go to Administration > Environment Management.

  2. Click the pen icon next to the name of the assigned environment to view the environment details.

  3. Click the Email icon to display and configure email settings.

  4. Under Incoming Emails from Cloud Application or User, configure the following settings:

    • Allowed Client IP Addresses – Enter any IP addresses approved for incoming mail.

    • Acceptable Domain Name/IP – Enter the domain names approved for incoming mail.

    • Domain Name – Enter the domain name used in your organization.

    • Certificate --

    • Under Outgoing Email Settings, configure the following settings:

      • Delivery options – Select Internet (MX) or Internal Relay. When Internal Relay is selected, mail for recipients not known to Office 365 is routed to your own email server before being delivered.

      • Acceptable Outgoing Domains/ IP Addresses – Enter any domains or IP addresses approved for sending mail.

  5. Click Save.


Configuring Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) for the Secure Email Gateway‌

Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) is an email security standard that helps detect whether messages are altered in transit between sending and receiving mail servers.

DKIM uses public-key cryptography to sign email with a responsible party's private key as it leaves a sending server. The receiving server uses a public key published to the DKIM's domain to verify the source of the message, and that the parts of the message included in the DKIM signature have not changed since the message was signed.

Once the signature is verified with the public key by the receiving server, the message passes DKIM and is considered authentic.


Enabling support for DKIM‌

Perform the following steps to enable support for DKIM.

  1. Go to Administration > Environment Management.

  2. Click on the pencil icon of the Default environment.

  3. Click the Email tab.

  4. Click the DKIM toggle to enable DKIM.

  5. Enter the Email domain. To enter multiple domains, separate each domain name with a comma.

  6. Make a note of the following details:

    • DNS Host Name (TXT Record Name)

    • TXT Record Value (DNS key)

  7. Go to the DNS settings page of the domain name provider (for example, Godaddy).

  8. Enter the DNS Host Name (TXT Record Name) and DNS Key (TXT Record Value) into the domain provider’s DNS settings page and click Add.

  9. On the Management Console, click Test. Once you see the Test status as Success, click Save.


Configuring DKIM for subdomains‌

If you want to configure DKIM for a subdomain, for example, nebula.mydomain.com, add the following configuration after completing the steps 1 through 4 in the previous section.

  1. Append the subdomain to the DNS Host Name (TXT Record Name) and enter into the domain provider’s DNS settings page.

    For example, if your domain is nebula.mydomain.com, then add the following entry into the DNS settings page of the domain name provider:

    lookoutsse1._domainkey.nebula

  2. Add the TXT Record Value (DNS key) you copied from the Management Console.

Configuring     DPaaS     settings         ‌

Data Protection as a Service (DPaaS) is a web service for performing encryption and tokenization. This service is used to perform tokenization by proxy services and to protect (or restore to clear text) emails forwarded from the email gateway. External clients can call data protection services for data and files using DPaaS. For example, the Data Transformation Tool (DTT) uses DPaaS for encryption of values in

.xlsx/.xls and .csv files.

To configure DPaaS settings:

  1. Go to Administration > Environment Management.

  2. Click the pen icon to the left of the cloud environment type for which to configure DPaaS settings.

  3. Click the DPaaS icon.

  4. Configure settings as described in the next section.


Server Settings‌

Enter or select values as follows.


Field

Description

Domain Name

The domain name used to access the DPaaS service — for example,

dpaas.corporatename.com.

Enter a domain name.

Certificate

The certificate used for this configuration.

Select a certificate name from the dropdown list. .


API Client‌

To allow external clients to access DPaaS web services, you can add clients to provide access to DPaaS services outside the Lookout gateway. The API client section of the DPaaS page lists any existing clients.



The client list shows the following information:


Field

Description

Client Name

The name given to the client.

Client Type

Determines the type of actions allowed for this client. The options are:

  • Tokenization -- a data protection client that enables tokenization and encryption.

  • Email -- enables email processing from outside the Lookout email gateway. Generally, external clients will not use this type.

  • DTT (Data Transformation Tool) -- a generic data protection client that enables tokenization and encryption. For more information about the DTT, see the Data Transformation Tool Gateway Reference Guide.


Field

Description

Restriction

Whether or not system access for the client should be open or restricted to a specific IP address. The options are:

  • Observed -- Access is tracked but not restricted.

  • Restrict -- Access is restricted to an IP address you specify. If you need access for additional addresses, you can create additional clients for each IP address for which access is needed.

Client IP

If you choose Restrict as the access option, the IP address you specify is shown here. If you choose Observed, this entry is blank.

Internal

False is an external client; true is an internal client. All clients created by users are external.

Internal proxy and email gateway clients are added automatically.

Last Seen

When the last connection attempt was made to DPaaS services for the client. For new clients, this entry will show Never Seen.

Status

The connection status for the client. For new clients, this entry will show Never Seen.

Actions

Actions you can perform once the client is created and saved. These include displaying the token for the client, resetting the token as needed, editing the client properties, and removing the client. These actions are explained in the following steps.


To add a new client:

  1. Click +Add Client.



  2. Enter or select the following information.


    Field

    Description

    Client Name

    Enter a meaningful name for the client.

    Client Type

    Select the type for the actions to be performed with this client --
