    Tokenization, Email, or DTT (Data Transformation Tool).

    Restrict Client

    Client IP

    If you choose Restrict, enter the IP address for which access will be allowed.

    • Select Observed to keep access open. All access attempts are tracked.

    • Select Restrict to limit access to a single IP address. If you need access for additional addresses, you can create additional clients for each IP address.

  3. Click Add. The client is added to the list.

  4. Click Save. The DPaaS settings you entered are saved, and the client is now active.

  5. Once you have saved the DPaaS settings, you can perform these additional actions for the new client:



Modify the name, client type, and restriction status.


Display the token for the client and copy it to your clipboard for distribution to authorized users.



Reset the token. Use this option if you suspect that the existing token might have been compromised. When you reset the token, you must distribute the new token to your authorized users. If a token is reset while a client connection already exists, the new token will not cause an interruption to the current connection. If the token is reset when there is not a connection, users must reauthenticate.


Remove the client if it is not needed (for example, if it enabled access for an IP address that is no longer being used).

Configuring              logs               ‌

You can configure the level of information for each log along with log file size and organization.

You can select different settings for each item and change them at any time based on your system activity and the type of information you need to track and analyze. Because much of the system activity takes place within nodes, you might need to provide more detail and greater log file capacity for the Node Server.

Note Log levels apply only to Lookout classes, not to third-party libraries. Perform the following steps to configure log settings.

  1. Go to Administration > Environment Management.

  2. Select the on-premise connector environment for which to apply log configuration settings.

  3. Click the Log Configuration icon.

  4. Click the Log Configuration Override toggle to display the log settings.

  5. Enter or select the following settings.


    Field

    Description

    Log Level

    Log Level refers to the type of content and level of detail included in logs. The options (in increasing level of detail) are:

    Select a log level.

    Number of Log Files

    The maximum number of files that can be maintained. When this number is reached, the oldest log file is deleted.

    Log File Max Size

    The maximum size allowed for a single log file. When the maximum file size is reached, the file is archived and information is stored in a new file. Each of the remaining logs is renamed to the next higher number. The current log is then compressed and renamed log-name.1.gz. A new log is started with log-name. So, if the maximum is 10, log-name.9.gz is the oldest file, and log-name.1.gz is the newest non-active file.

    • Warn — Includes only errors or warnings of actual or possible problems.

    • Info — Includes informational text about system processes and status, along with warnings and errors.

    • Debug — Includes all informational text, warnings and errors, and more detailed information about system conditions. This information can aid in diagnosing and troubleshooting system issues.

    • Trace — The most detailed level of information. This information can be used by developers to focus on a precise area of the system.

  6. Click Save.

Importing and exporting keys and applications                 ‌

You can import and export applications and keys between one Management Server and another, using an XML file that stores the values of the applications and keys. You can use the exported XML file to import the keys and applications to another Management Server, or you can save the exported file to use as a historical snapshot before you make any changes to your Management Server configurations.

From the Management Console, you can select the keys and applications to export from the list of available items.

For keys, the list includes the following information.


Name

Description

Key Server

Associated with

The name of the key.

The current status of the key (for example, active or inactive), and the key expiration date.

The name of the key server specified for the key.

The names of the connectors and applications with which the key is currently associated.

Each name is a combination of the connector name and the application name (for example,

ConnectorName/AppName).

For applications, the list includes the following information:


Name

Description

Connector type

Associated with

The name of the application.

The current status of the assigned key (for example, active or inactive), and the key

expiration date.

The name of the connector to which the application is assigned.

The name of the keys with which the application is associated.


Exporting keys and applications‌

  1. From the Management Console, choose Administration > System Settings > Export / Import.

  2. Make sure that the Export tab is displayed. Fields with a colored border at the left require a value.

  3. In the Metadata Configuration section, enter a name and (optionally) a description for the XML file to which you want to export.

  4. Enter a password. Confirm the password by entering it again in the Confirm Password field. This password will apply to all of the keys and applications you select.

  5. The XML file you generate contains details about the keys and applications available in your system.

To export keys:

  1. Click the toggle to display the list of available keys.



  2. Check the boxes for the keys you want to export. To export all keys, click the box at the top to the left of the Name field.

  3. Click Export.

  4. Save the generated XML file.

  5. Select a location to store the generated XML file. For the file name, accept the default name or enter a different name.

Once the file is saved, you can import it to another Management Server, or save it for historical purposes.

To export applications:

  1. Click the toggle to display the list of available applications.



  2. Check the boxes for the applications you want to export. To export all applications, check the box at the top to the left of the Name field.

  3. Click Export.

  4. Select the location on your computer to save the XML file. You can accept the default file name (the name of the application) or choose a different file name.

  5. Save the XML file.

The XML file can now be imported to another Management Server. If you do not need to import the keys or applications, you can save the XML file to use as a snapshot in time of the current key and application configurations on your Management Server.


Importing keys and applications‌

You can import keys and applications from another Management Server using an exported and saved XML file. Once the import is successful, the imported keys and applications are stored on the Management Server. You must then associate any applications with an environment before they can be enabled and run.

To import keys and applications:

  1. Go to Administration > System Settings > Export / Import.

  2. Click the Import tab.

  3. Click Import Metadata.

  4. Select an XML file to import.

  5. Select a key or an application to which the import will apply.

  6. Click Import.

    If you cannot complete the import process, the cause might be any of these situations:

    • You are trying to import an XML file that has keys and applications with names already present in the Management Server.

    • A key might not be available.

    • The XML file might have been modified before the import.

    • The application’s specified connector version is not available (a warning), or no version of the application’s connector is available (blocks import).

    • The supplied password does not match that used during export.

      If you receive a warning message, you will be asked if you want to continue the import. Once the import is complete, you must configure the environment for imported applications.

      Configuring cloud discovery settings     ‌

      You can configure settings to manage and monitor information related to cloud discovery. The following topics are provided:

    • Risk Factor Weight

    • Purge Control

    • Knowledge Base

    • User Privacy

    • GDPR Configuration

    • Groups of Interest


Risk Factor Weight‌

Secure Cloud Access calculates cloud risk scores by applying the following four major risk factor attributes: security, compliance, environment, and privacy. Each attribute contains sub-attributes that are also weighted and scored. The calculation is stored in the Knowledge Base.

Because organizations have different security and compliance needs, modifications can be made to the default risk factor attribute levels by adjusting attribute weight percentages or by modifying the score itself.

By analyzing the risk distribution applied to cloud applications and by applying risk factor attribute weighting, the Knowledge Base assesses and displays the calculated risk scores for the cloud applications used in your organization. If you do not customize the risk factor attributes or the risk distribution, the Management Console displays the risk scores as calculated in the Knowledge Base.

If Lookout has enabled GDPR configurations for you, these charts will also show GDPR compliance.

Adjusting risk factor weighting might change (customize) the scores, whereas adjusting the risk distribution index changes score definitions of what is considered low, medium and high.

The Risk Factor Weight page (Administration > System Settings > Risk Factor Weight) displays the risk factor attributes and their corresponding percentages of importance. Risk factors with higher percentages represent factors of higher importance when analyzing the risk scores of cloud applications.

You can adjust the percentage of the weight factors to represent what you regard as most to least importance. For example, if an application's security factor rating is most important to your organization's needs, you can change the security weight factor to a percentage that has a greater value than the other factors. By adjusting the percentage of the security factor to a greater percentage, you increase the risk score to the cloud applications with poor security ratings.

The following table lists and describes the risk factor categories.


Risk factor

Description

Environment

Evaluates the overall conditions of an application such as its hosting location, the type of data being stored, and how the data is being stored

Compliance

Evaluates policy, law, and regulatory compliance

Security

Evaluates an application’s security risk and vulnerability.

Privacy

Evaluates the privacy policy for a cloud.

GDPR

(if enabled)

If GDPR configurations have been enabled for you, scores for GDPR compliance will also be reflected. For more information, see GDPR Configuration.

Adjusting risk factor weighting percentages‌

  1. Select Administration > System Settings > Risk Factor Weight.

  2. Under the Risk Factor Weight chart, use the sliders to adjust the percentages of each risk factor you want to change.

    The risk scores change according to your adjustments. Your changes are reflected in the pie chart.

  3. Click Save.

  4. A confirmation page shows the intended changes.

  5. Click Yes to accept the changes.

  6. (Optional) lick Reset to return to the default weights.


Adjusting distribution of cloud risk scores‌

Risk Distribution refers to the distribution of risk scores associated with each cloud. Depending on a cloud's risk score, the cloud is classified as high, medium, or low risk. Each risk score is indicated by a number from 1 to 10, with 1 being the lowest risk and 10 being the highest. The numbers in the Risk Distribution graph represent the number of cloud applications associated with each level.

To adjust the distribution of risk scores:

  1. In the Risk Distribution chart, use the sliders to adjust the distribution rating.


    The distribution changes according to your adjustments. Your changes are reflected in the pie chart.

  2. Click Save.

  3. A confirmation page shows the intended changes.

  4. Click Yes to accept the changes.

  5. (Optional) Click Reset to return to the default Risk Distribution Scores.


Purge Control‌

The Purge Control options enable you to remove old data automatically. You can specify the number of days to store data before it is purged by accepting the default values shown, or by editing the number for each option.

To enable or edit purging controls:

  1. Go to Administration > System Settings > Purge Control.

  2. Enter the storage limit (in days) for each option as follows:

    • Queryable data – Accept the default value of 180 days or enter any value from 0 to 365 days. Data will be purged after the number of days you specify.

    • Unrecognized domains – Accept the default value of 30 days or enter any value from 0 to 90 days. Data will be purged after the number of days you specify.

  3. 3. Click Save.

Purging goes into effect immediately after you click Save. On a regular basis, an automatic purge runs daily to delete older data.


Knowledge Base‌

The Knowledge Base setting enables you to update the Knowledge Base manually or automatically to reflect the latest information about discovered cloud applications and risk scores.

To configure automatic or manual Knowledge Base updates:

  1. Select Administration > System Settings > Knowledge Base.



  2. Configure automatic or manual updates.

    • For automatic knowledge base updates, leave the default Knowledge Base Auto Update setting enabled. To disable automatic updates, click the toggle.

    • For manual updates, click Update. The knowledge base is updated, and the Last Updated

information is modified to show the date and time of the update.


Contributing to the Knowledge Base‌

You can contribute to the Knowledge Base by suggesting edits to the current risk score or categories of a cloud. You can enter your suggestions by clicking Suggest Edit in the cloud detail view.

Perform the following steps to complete the form when it appears. All fields are optional. Complete the form to the best of your knowledge. The more information you provide, the better the research team can evaluate your suggestions.

Enter suggestions for general information about the cloud. (The existing values appear in boldface next to the field label.)


Name

Enter the proposed name for the cloud.


Category

Select one or more proposed categories. If a preferred category is not listed, click Add New and enter the category name.

Then, click Apply.

Risk Score

Select a risk score you feel is appropriate for the cloud.

Reasons for your suggestion

Enter a reason for your suggestion (up to 500 characters).

Click Show Advanced Options to configure additional settings. Then, complete the information as appropriate.

Complete the Environment section.


Cloud Hosting Location

Select a country that indicates the hosting location for the cloud.

Control Over Hosting Environment

Select the hosting provider. Then:

Select Own datacenter, or select 3rd party datacenter, and check the boxes for the selections that apply to this cloud. If a data center is not listed, click Add New and enter the name. Click Apply when done.

Type of Data

Check the boxes that apply to the type of data for your suggestion or Select All. For each data type, click the right arrow icon at the left to view additional choices. If a data type is not listed, click Add New and enter the name for the data type.

SLA by Cloud Provider

Select Yes, No, or Unknown to indicate whether an SLA exists for the cloud.

Service Outage

Enter the percentage of service outages reported over the last year.

Multi-Tenancy

Select Yes, No, or Unknown to indicate if the service provider supports multi-tenancy.

Number of Users

Select the number of users for this cloud.

Customer Support

Select the type(s) of customer service for this cloud and click

Apply.

Type of Usage

Select the type(s) of usage for this cloud and click Apply.

Business Continuity

Select the method by which business continuity plans are verified – Documented, Tested, or Unknown.


Complete the Compliance section.


Compliance

Select the types of compliance met by this cloud. If a compliance type is not listed, click Add New and enter the name. Then, click Apply.

Known Compliance Violations

Select any known non-compliance by checking the appropriate boxes and click Apply.


Certificates

Select the certificates applicable to this cloud and click Apply. If a certificate is not listed, click Add New, and enter the certificate name.

Complete the Privacy & Security section.


Privacy Policy Link

Enter the applicable privacy policy link

Privacy Statement Violation

Select Yes, No, or Unknown to indicate whether a privacy statement violation exists.

Security controls

Select the type of security controls for this cloud.

Data at Rest Encryption

Select Yes, No, or Unknown to indicate whether the cloud service provider encrypts data at rest.

Login Security

Select the security options provided by the cloud and click

Apply.


Complete the Contact Information.


Are You the Cloud Provider?

Select Yes or No to indicate whether you are the cloud provider.

Email

Enter your email address if you want Lookout to follow up with you by email.

Phone Number

Enter your phone number if you want Lookout to follow up with you by phone.

Click Submit after entering all of your proposed edits. Your suggestions will be sent to the Lookout Knowledge Base.


User Privacy‌

Secure Cloud Access provides options to protect sensitive information, such as names, addresses, credit card numbers, or email addresses, that can be used to identify or locate individual persons. This type of information is known as personally identifiable information (often referred to as PII).

The User Privacy page provides options to enable anonymization of PII data for cloud discovery logs, so that PII information for users cannot be identified in notifications and other correspondence. In Shadow IT reports, however, you can download information in plain text.


Enabling PII data anonymization‌

  1. Go to Administration > System Settings > User Privacy.

  2. Click the slider to activate anonymization of PII data.

  3. Select Purge to purge existing PII data or Encrypt to encrypt it.

  4. Click the slider to allow Shadow IT reports to be downloaded in plain text with PII anonymization enabled.

  5. Click Save.

Searching for anonymized data in user lists‌

When PII anonymization is enabled, you can search for and view user names in plain text from the Users

page in cloud discovery. To do so:

  1. Go to Discover > Shadow IT.

  2. Choose User. With PII anonymization enabled, user information is displayed in encrypted form.

  3. In the navigation bar at the left, click the check box to enable searching for protected data.

  4. When prompted, enter your login credentials.

    Once the system authenticates your credentials, you can search for user names in plain text.

  5. Enter a name on which to search. The user information appears in plain text.


GDPR Configuration‌

European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) took effect in May of 2018. Organizations globally must follow stringent requirements to protect private information and will face severe penalties for breaches. GDPR has international reach, covering the personal information of European citizens – wherever it is distributed globally.

Secure Cloud Access can help you track details regarding GDPR compliance in your organization by monitoring risk factors. To enable this capability in Secure Cloud Access, you must contact Lookout Support. Once GDPR Reporting has been enabled, you can evaluate risk factor weightings and distribution for GDPR.

To do so, perform the following steps.

  1. Select Administration > System Settings.

  2. Select GDPR Configuration.

    If GDPR Reporting has been enabled, the GDPR Reporting toggle button will show an enabled status. If the toggle button still appears as disabled, contact Lookout Support.

    GDPR values are available in the following areas:

    • Shadow IT report (GDPR values will be included in the PDF)

    • GDPR compliance information in the risk score information for a cloud, as shown in the following example. (To view these details, click the > arrow next to a cloud on the Cloud applications page.) GDPR values will also be included when you export information for a cloud.


    • Risk factor weighting customization (System Settings > Risk Factor Weight).


Groups of interest‌

For hosted deployments, groups of interest are sets of groups that an enterprise can use to monitor and apply controls on cloud applications. Applying groups of interest eliminates the need to sync all groups from the cloud / enterprise directory to the Secure Cloud Access platform.

Groups of interest are determined from context settings for DRM policies.

To view, add, or remove groups of interest, go to Administration > System Settings > Groups of Interest.

From the Groups of Interest page, you can view the list of existing groups and their source.

To add or remove groups of interest:

  1. Select the group or groups to add or remove. You can select up to 15 groups at a time.

  2. Click Add Groups or Remove Groups.

  3. When prompted, click Yes to confirm the addition or removal.

    Creating and managing notifications and alerts                     ‌

    Secure Cloud Access provides a flexible and comprehensive set of tools for creating notifications for policy enforcement and communication of critical messages regarding protection of data. You can create notifications for a variety of data security needs and cloud applications, devices, and network environments. You can then apply those preconfigured notifications to multiple inline and API access policies. Because notifications are created separately from policies, you can apply notifications consistently across policies and customize them conveniently as needed.

    You can also view an audit trail of past notifications and export this information for historical purposes. Notifications are created and managed from these areas in the Management Console:

    • Administration > Enterprise Integration > Notification Channels for creating channels used by cloud applications

    • Administration > Notification Management for creating templates and building notifications with the appropriate templates and channels

    • Administration > System Settings > Alert Configuration for setting threshold values to receive email notifications

The workflow for creating notifications includes these steps:

  1. Create channels to define the communication method for issuing a notification.

  2. Create templates to specify the text and format for the notification.

  3. Create the notification itself, which includes the channel and the template needed for the notification. Once you have created a notification, you can apply it to the appropriate policies.

    The following topics provide instructions for creating notifications.

    • Creating notification channels

    • Creating notification templates

    • Creating notifications to apply to policies


Creating notification channels‌

Notification channels define how the notification will be communicated. Secure Cloud Access provides several types of channels for various notification types. Channels are available for email notifications, messages on Slack cloud applications, and marker files.

The Notification Channels page (Administration > Enterprise Integration > Notification Channels) lists the notification channels that have been created.

To view details for a channel, click the eye icon to the left of the channel name. To close the details view, click Cancel.

To filter the columns displayed, click the Filter icon at the upper right, and check the columns to hide or show.

To download a CSV file with a list of channels, click the Download icon at the upper right.

To create a new notification channel:

  1. Go to Administration > Enterprise Integration > Notification Channels and click New.

  2. Enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional but recommended) for the new channel.

  3. Select a notification type. The options are:

    • Email (for notifications as email)

    • Proxy (for proxy-related notifications)

    • Slack (for notifications pertaining to Slack applications)

    • ServiceNow Incident (for notifications pertaining to ServiceNow)

    • Marker (for notifications as marker files)

  4. If you selected either the Slack or ServiceNow Incident types, the Cloud Name field appears. Select a cloud application to which the channel will apply.

  5. Save the channel.


    Creating notification templates‌

    Templates define the text and format of a notification. Most templates offer an HTML or plain text format option and offer base text that you can customize.

    The Templates tab on the Notifications page (Administration > Notification Management) lists predefined templates from the knowledge base and enables you to create additional templates.

    You can define the following attributes for each template:

    • Name — The name by which the template will be referenced.

    • Type – The action or event for which the template is used. For example, you can create templates to notify users about Slack messages or to send email notifications about alerts or jobs completed.

    • Subject — A brief description of the template’s function.

    • Format — The format of the template for the application, connector, or function. Options include Email, Slack (format and channel), ServiceNow, SMS, Proxy, Reporting, and configuration changes.

    • Updated On — The date and time on which the template was created or last updated.

    • Updated User – The email address of the user to which the template applies.

    • Actions – Options for modifying or deleting a template.

To create a new notification template:

  1. Go to Administration > Notification Management.

  2. Click the Templates tab and click New.

  3. Enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional).

  4. Select a template Category. This is the type of action, event, or policy for which the template will be used.



  5. Select a Format for the template. The formats available depend on the category you chose in the previous step. In this example, the formats listed are for the Cloud Access Policy category.


  6. Select a notification Type. The options listed depend on the format you chose in the previous step.


  7. Enter the content for the template in the text area at the right. Scroll down to the areas where you want to enter content.

  8. Select any variables you want to use from the list at the left. Place the cursor at the point where the variable should be inserted and click the variable name. The list of available variables will vary depending on the format and type of template you are creating.

    Note

    When creating device threat-level templates for Cloud Authentication and Cloud Access Control policies, use the MES App Dynamic Link variable to insert a dynamic link value instead of hard- coding the URL for the link.


  9. If you are creating an email template, select HTML or Text as the delivery format, and enter a subject.

  10. Click Preview at the upper right to see how your template content will be displayed.


  11. Save the template.


Creating notifications‌

Once you have created notification channels and templates, you can create the actual notifications that can be applied to policies. Each notification uses a selected channel and template and is distributed according to the frequency you specify.

To create a new notification:

  1. Click the Notifications tab and click New.

  2. Enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional).

  3. Select a notification Category.

  4. Select a Notification Channel.

  5. Select a Notification Template. The templates in the dropdown list depend on the channel you selected in the previous step.


  6. Depending on the notification channel you selected, you will be prompted to enter additional information. Here are two examples.

    • For an email channel:

      • Select an email template, then check the types of recipients. If you checked Others, enter recipient names separated by commas.

      • Select a notification frequency – Immediate or Batched. For Batched, select a batch frequency and a time interval (minutes or days).

    • For a Slack channel:

      • Select a notification template.

      • Select one or more Slack channels.

  7. Save the notification.

The new notification is added to the list.


Creating activity alerts‌

You can create activity alerts for onboarded (managed) cloud applications and for cloud discovery.

For managed cloud applications

For each managed-cloud alert, the Activity Alerts page shows:

  • Name -- The name of the alert

  • Activity – The type of activity to which the alert applies

  • Notification -- The name of the associated notification for this alert.

  • Updated on -- The date and time on which the alert was updated. The time is based on the Time Zone setting configured in the System Settings page.

  • Updated by – The valid username for the user who last updated the alert, or a system update.

  • Status – A toggle that indicates the status of the alert (active or inactive).

  • Actions – An icon that, when clicked, enables you to edit information about the alert.

  • To view the details for an alert, click the icon to the left of the alert name. Click Cancel to return to the list view.

    For cloud discovery

    For each cloud-discovery alert, the Activity Alerts page displays the following information:

  • Name – The name of the alert.

  • Updated on – The date and time at which the alert was last updated. The time is based on the time zone setting configured in the System Settings page.

  • Updated by – The valid username of the user who last updated the alert, or a system update.

  • Notification – The name of the associated notification.

  • Status – A toggle that indicates the alert status (active or inactive).

  • Actions – An icon that, when clicked, enables you to edit information about the alert.

  • To view the details for an alert, click the icon to the left of the alert name. Click Cancel to return to the list view.

    Types of alerts‌

    For onboarded cloud applications, you can create three types of alerts:

  • Cloud Activity, which includes alerts about content activity on the cloud application you specify

  • External System Connectivity, which includes alerts involving your configurations for external connectivity (enterprise DLP, log agent, or SIEM)

  • Tenant Activity, which provides alerts for anomalies (geolocations, authentications, content deletion, downloads by size and by count) and changes cloud to risk scores


Creating alerts for managed cloud applications‌

  1. Go to Monitor > Activity Alerts.

  2. In the Managed Clouds tab, click New.

  3. Enter an Alert Name.

  4. Select an Alert Type.

    1. For Cloud Activity alerts, enter or select the following information:


      • Cloud Account -- The cloud application for the alert.

      • Activity -- Check the boxes for one or more activities.


      • Filters -- Select the filters for this alert activity type.


        • For Time Window, select a day and time range in which the activity occurs.

        • For Threshold, enter the number of events, the duration, and time increment (Mins or Hours) for this activity (for example, 1 event every 4 hours).

        • The Aggregate Alert Counts toggle is enabled by default, which indicates that threshold aggregation occurs at the cloud application level. To enable activity count aggregation at the individual user level, click the toggle to disable it.

        • For User Groups:

        • Click in the box to the right.

        • Double-click a directory name.

        • Select a group from the list that appears and click the arrow to move it to the

          Selected Groups column.

        • Click Save.

        • To specify more than one filter, click the + button and select another filter.

      • Notifications — Select a notification to send with this alert. The options are based on the notifications you created.

    2. For External System Connectivity alerts, select the following information:


      • Services – Check the boxes for one or more services, including Enterprise DLP, Log Agent, and SIEM.

      • Frequency – Select Once or Send Reminders. For Send Reminders, enter a reminder quantity and time increment (day or hour). For example, 2 reminders per day.


      • Notifications – Select a notification from the list.

    3. For Tenant Activity alerts, select the following information:


      • Activity Type – Select an activity, either Anomaly or Risk Score Change. For Anomaly, select one or more anomaly types to include in notifications.

      • Filters – Select Time Window. Then select a day and time range in which the activity occurs.


      • Notifications – Select a notification to use for the alert.


Creating alerts for Cloud Discovery‌

  1. Click the Cloud Discovery tab and click New.

  2. Enter the following information:



  3. Enter a Name for the alert.

  4. Select a Content Type.

    • Users — Enter one or more valid user email addresses for users to be included in the alert. Separate each email address with a comma. Click Save.

    • User Groups — Check one or more the user groups, or check Select All. Click Save.

    • Cloud Risks — Check one or more cloud risk levels.

    • Cloud Category — Check one or more cloud application categories, for example, Cloud Storage or Collaboration.

    • Total Bytes Threshold — Enter a number (in kilobytes) that represents the size threshold for triggering an alert. Then, enter a duration quantity and interval.

    • To specify more than one content type, enter the information in the second dropdown list. To specify additional content types, click the + icon at the right, and enter the information in the additional dropdown lists.

  5. Select a Notification for the type to be used when the alert is sent.

  6. Save the alert.


Configuring notification and alert options in System Settings‌

You can configure threshold values for email notifications, and configure logos for templates, from System Settings.


Selecting alert configurations‌

  1. Go to Administration > System Settings > Alert Configuration.

  2. Click Create an Alert.

  3. In the Alert Configuration window, enter the following information:


    Field

    Description

    Event Name

    The type of event that generates the alert. The options are:

    • CPU

    • Memory

    • Disks

    • Threads

    • Service Down

    • Login Failure

    • Certificate Event

    • Service Up

    • Key Creation

    • Node Management

    • Node State Change

    • User Management

    • Connector Management

    • Node Communication Action

    • Environment Management


    Field

    Description

    Trigger value/Greater or Less

    Note

    Alerts fall into two categories:

    This setting pertains to alerts for thresholds. It does not apply to the strict occurrence of events such as a login

    failure or the creation of a key.

    The limit for an event which, if more or less than specified value, triggers an alert. For example:

    Alert notifications are sent to the specified recipient. If you selected Show on the Home page, the alert is listed on the Management Console dashboard. Although administrators are typically most often interested in events that indicate greater-than status, sometimes you might want to know when events drop below the trigger to indicate a possible problem (for example, no activity appears to be taking place).

    Environments

    The environments to which the alert applies. You can choose specific environments or all environments.

    Connectors

    If connectors are available, only alerts related to those connectors and their associated applications will be visible.

    Email list

    The email addresses of those who should receive the alert notifications. The most common recipient is the system administrator, but you can add other addresses. Enter each recipient email address, separating the addresses by commas. System Administrator and Key Administrator will include all users with the matching role. This list can be empty if you only want it to show in the Alert

    Messages section of the Management Console.

    Alert interval

    How often the alert should be sent. Select a number and type of interval (hour, minute, or day). Select 0 to get all instances of an event type, such as Key Creation.

    Show Alerts

    Click the toggle button to enable alerts to be listed in the Alert Messages section of the Management Console dashboard. You might want to use this option for alerts relating to more serious conditions. Those alert messages will be seen on the dashboard whenever the Home page is displayed.

    Description

    Enter a description of the alert.

    • those driven by thresholds being crossed, and

    • those driven by events that occur.

    • If the value for CPU is greater than 90, and system CPU usage goes up to 91%, an alert is triggered.

    • If the value for CPU is less than 10%, and the system CPU usage drops to 9%, an alert is triggered.


  4. Save the configuration.


Editing an alert configuration‌

You can edit information about an alert if the conditions related to the alert have changed — for example, if the severity of the alert has increased or decreased, the condition applies to more or fewer environments, or you need to modify recipient email addresses or the alert description.

  1. From the System Settings page, choose Alert Configuration.

  2. Select the alert configuration you want to edit.

  3. Click the pencil icon.

  4. In the Alert Configuration dialog box, modify the alert information as needed.

  5. Click Save.


Deleting an alert configuration‌

You can delete an alert configuration if the related event no longer applies, or if you do not need to monitor the event.

  1. From the System Settings page, choose Alert Configuration.

  2. Select the alert you want to delete.

  3. Click the trash can icon.

  4. When prompted, confirm deleting the alert.

  5. Click Save.

    Configuring SSE for Secure Private Access ‌

    Secure Private Access is an IT security model that enables enterprises to apply stricter controls for access to information in a private network from individuals both inside and outside of a network perimeter. Because the Secure Private Access architecture is not tied to a specific technology, its benefits can be applied to many types of use cases, technologies, and devices.

    Because data can flow across many internal and external locations on a variety of devices (some over which the enterprise might not have complete control), the opportunities for data to be exposed and compromised, even within the confines of a network, are far greater than before.

    Secure Private Access provides additional security both inside and outside the defined software perimeter (SDP). The assumption of trust within a network is eliminated. All users and devices must be authenticated before access is authorized. DLP content inspection can be applied to private apps.

    The integration of Secure Private Access into Lookout SSE addresses this greater risk in several ways:

    • Provides stronger enterprise security through a "principle of least privilege" approach to data access, in or out of a network. This approach removes the assumption of trust within a network and addresses the increasing need to protect data that resides on private apps in a network as well as data shared with external collaborators.

    • Prevents data breaches resulting from lateral movement of malware from compromised devices.

    • Enables full app "cloaking" by eliminating open firewall ports and blocking potentially malicious or damaging connections.

    • Offers clientless and agentless access to the web (HTTP, HTTPS, RDP, and SSH) and to a wider range of applications.

    • Extends full Secure Cloud Access and Secure Internet Access controls, including DLP content inspection, to private apps.

      When a user starts the process of accessing an enterprise application, Secure Private Access applies the appropriate controls along the path through the gateway and to the application. Users can access both HTTPS and non-HTTPS applications.


      Onboarding and configuring Secure Private Access for enterprise applications‌

      The following sections outline the workflow to onboard Secure Private Access for enterprise applications, configuring connections, configuring environments and nodes for on-premise use of Secure Private Access, and monitoring options for activity related to Secure Private Access.

    • Step 1 - Enable Secure Private Access (ZTNA) from the Management Console

    • Step 2 - (Optional) Create a category for networks

    • Step 3 - Create connectors for gateway access

    • Step 4 - Download the required packages based on the OS version

    • Step 5 - Install the on-premise connector

    • Step 6 - Onboard enterprise applications for Secure Private Access

Step 1 – Enable Secure Private Access (ZTNA) from the Management Console‌

In System Settings, you can add the configurations to enable the web proxy to function as a Software Defined Perimeter (SDP) gateway, enabling exposure to on-premise applications without the need for a VPN.

  1. Go to Administration > System Settings and click ZTNA Gateway in the left menu.

  2. If the Enable ZTNA toggle is not enabled, click it to display the Secure Private Access (ZTNA) settings.

  3. Select the Connection as Web Socket. The following details are displayed:

    • Forward Proxy Domain – The format for forward proxy domain. Note the Z in the URL, which indicates Secure Private Access (ZTNA).

    • Reverse Proxy Domain – The format for the reverse proxy domain.

    • Tunnel EndPoint – The information used by a ZTNA connector deployed in the enterprise to enable access to an on-prem application via the Lookout gateway.

  4. Click Save.


Step 2 – (Optional) Create a category for networks‌

Note Perform these configurations only if you are using the Lookout client for Windows.


  1. Log in to the Management Console.


  2. Go to Protect > Category Management, and click +New.


  3. Enter a Category Name.


  4. Category Type – from the drop down list, select IP.


  5. Category Values – Configure a range for the Network. Enter IP addresses, subnet masks, or IP ranges on separate lines. Click Save.


    Note Make sure to provide all the networks that are connected to the enterprise applications. The IP or subnets should include a private DNS server IP address.


    Example:

    192.169.1.0/24

    192.168.1.100


    Avoid spaces between lines.


    Note: The ZTNA tunnel may not come up if the ZTNA configuration has overlapping IP addresses. For example, if you provide two subnets such as 10.1.0.0/16 and 10.1.0.0/24, then the non-http tunnel may not come up. We recommend not to configure overlapping IP addresses.


  6. Click Save.

Step 3 – Create connectors for gateway access‌

Create environments for the connectors used in the data path to access applications. This process includes two steps:

  • Step 3a - Create an environment that supports Secure Private Access (or update an existing environment for Secure Private Access support).

  • Step 3b - Create one or more nodes for that environment.


Step 3a – Create an environment to serve as an on-premise connector‌

  1. Go to Administration > Environment Management and click New.

  2. Enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional).

  3. Enter one or more valid IP v4 addresses for the connection. If you enter multiple IP addresses, separate each address with a comma.

    Note When a node connects to the Node Manager, a Node Manager validates the node’s IP address against what is configured in the environment. If an on-premise node connects, the Node Manager will see the node’s public IP address, not the private address. As a result, the IP address for the node needs to be public.

    To determine the public IP address for the connector machine, run this command:

    curl https://ifoonfig.me/

  4. Click Next.

  5. In the Connector Settings page, select the TLS settings.

    Note If you have enabled Secure Private Access but disabled it later, the ZTNA connector services must be restarted.

  6. From the User Remediation for Invalid Certificates dropdown list, select one of these options.

    • Self Remediate - select this option if you want the Lookout service to accept self-signed certificates for your enterprise web apps.

    • Deny - denies an invalid certificate.

    • Warn - sends a warning message using a preconfigured template.

  7. Click the ZTNA toggle to enable the services to apply to this environment.

  8. (Optional) Enable the Enable Network Level Access toggle.

    Note This is required for network segment-based access that is available only for Windows clients.

  9. Enter the DNS Server IP. This will enable the client to resolve Secure Private Access domains.

  10. Enter the DNS Suffix.

  11. Select a configured network category from the Configured IP Networks dropdown list and click

    Apply.

  12. To enable other services, click their toggles and select the services.

  13. Click Next. If you want to override system log settings, click the toggle.

  14. Save the environment.

Note If you have enabled Secure Private Access but disable it later, the ZTNA connector services must be restarted.

For more information about environments and how they are used in SSE, see Creating and managing environments.


Step 3b – Create a node for the on-premise connector environment‌

Once you have created an on-premise connector environment, you can assign one or more nodes to it. Perform these steps to create a new node and assign it to the environment.

  1. Go to Administration > Node Management and click New.

  2. Enter a node Name (required) and a Description (optional).

  3. Select an Environment from the dropdown list. Every node must be associated with an environment.

  4. Select ZTNA Connector as the Service to apply to this node.

  5. Click Add Node.

    A confirmation message is displayed with the token created for the new node.



  6. Click Copy to Clipboard to copy the Node Unique Name and the Token ID.

  7. Save the copied items in a text file. You will need this information when you install the connector.

For more information about nodes and how they are used in Secure Cloud Access, see Setting up and managing nodes.


Step 4 – Download the required packages‌

This section provides instructions for downloading the DEB package for Ubuntu

  1. In the Management Console, go to Administration > System Settings.

  2. Select Downloads from the left menu.

  3. Select the on-premise connector DEB file from the list and click the Download icon at the right.

  4. Save the downloaded file and copy it for installation on the appropriate VM. You will use this file for installation of the on-premise connector.


Step 5 – Install the on-premise connector‌

Once you have created an on-premise connector environment and associated a node with it, you can install the on-premise connector on the VM or machine from which the applications or services are accessible.

Hardware and software requirements

The machine on which you install the connector must meet the following hardware and software requirements:

Operating system Ubuntu 20.04.5 LTS (Focal Fossa)

CPU 4 core

RAM 16 GB

Disk space 100 GB or more

JDK JDK 11 and above

Notes

  • The latest Ubuntu OS version that Lookout supports for the Secure Private Access (ZTNA) connector is 20.04.5.

  • Lookout supports OpenSSH 8.2 or lower for SSH over Secure Private Access.

  • The SSH over Secure Private Access supports RSA and DSA keys.


    Firewall settings

    Allow outbound HTTPS traffic.

    Allow the following outbound WSS connections:

  • Based on the location of your tenant, provide the Node Management URL. For Europe Central-1 [euc1] wss://nm.eucl.lkt.cloud:443/nodeManagement

    For the United States West-2 [usw2]

    wss://nm.usw2.lkt.cloud:443/nodeManagement

    Note You can identify the Node management URL from your Management Console URL as follows:

  • If your Management Console URL is

    https: maxonz-ms.eucl.lkt.cloud/account/index.html#login

    Then your Node Management URL is

    Euc1.lkt.cloud


    Port numbers

  • UDP ports 500 and 4500 must be open on the machine where you install the Secure Private Access (ZTNA) connector to establish an IPSec tunnel.

  • Port 8443 must be open for internal communication.

  • Inbound TLS connections need to be allowed.

  • Private certificates need to be added for the Java TrustStore on the machine where you install the Secure Private Access (ZTNA) connector.

Installation procedure for Ubuntu


Prerequisites


Before installing the connector, upgrade the Ubuntu packages by running the following commands as a root user:

apt-get update apt upgrade

Installation steps

Use the DEB file you downloaded in step 4 to install the connector. Perform these steps to complete the installation.

IMPORTANT You must run the on-premise enterprise connector installation as a non-root user.

  1. Run the following command to start the installation in the Linux instance:

    [ubuntu@localhost home]# sudo apt install ./enterprise- connector_<version>_amd64.deb

    Where <version> is the current DEB file version in the Management Console. The following libs are installed as part of this installation.

    libcairo2, libjpeg-turbo8, libpng16-16, uuid-runtime, libwebp6, freerdp2- x11, libvorbisfile3, pulseaudio, libssh2-1, libpango-1.0-0, strongswan, strongswan-swanctl, libcharon-standard-plugins, libcharon-extra-plugins, charon-systemd, libfmt-dev, libprotobuf-dev, libprotobuf-c-dev

    When prompted to install packages, enter Y (yes).

  2. Run the following command to execute the installation configuration script.

    sudo /opt/ciphercloud/node-server/install.sh

    System response:

    Initializing node-server install script. Please wait..

  3. Respond to the system prompts as follows:

    Please enter Management Server endpoint [wss://nm:443/nodeManagement]:

    Based on the location of your tenant, provide the Node Management URL:

    For Europe Central-1 [euc1]:

    wss://nm.euc1.lkt.cloud:443/nodeManagement

    For United States West-2 [usw2]:

    wss://nm.usw2.lkt.cloud:443/nodeManagement

    Note You can identify the Node Management URL from your Management Console URL as follows:

    If your Management Console URL is

    https://maxonz-ms.euc1.lkt.cloud/account/index.html#login

    Then your Node Management URL is

    euc1.lkt.cloud

    1. Enter the default option shown or enter the URL for this installation.

      Management Server endpoint: <Node Management endpoint URL>

    2. Enter the unique ID for this tenant.

      Input Tenant Id: <tenant name>

    3. Enter the unique name for the Node Server.

      Input Node Server Unique Name: <node_name>

    4. Enter the API token (click the API Token button in the Configuration tab)

      Input Node Server Token: <Node API token>

      Once Node server installation is done. Start node server using ‘sudo service node-server start’.

    5. Enter an option (y or n) to install with the upstream proxy.

    Note This option is not supported for the Secure Private Access (ZTNA) connector. Type n and press Enter.

    ===================================================

    Node server installation is complete.

  4. Run the following command to start the Node Server:

sudo service node-server start


Step 6 – Onboard enterprise applications for Secure Private Access (ZTNA)‌

To use Secure Private Access controls for data access, you need to create enterprise applications. You can create and manage such applications through the Management Console and apply policies to them.

Before performing these steps, be sure that the ZTNA connector with SSH and RDP embedded services has been installed and is running.

  1. Go to Administration > App Management and click New.

  2. Choose Enterprise Apps from the dropdown list.

  3. Enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional) for the application and click Next.


  4. Select App Authentication and App Access as the protection mode.

  5. Click Next and enter or select the configuration settings.

  6. App Type -- From the dropdown list, choose a type. The options are:

    • HTTPS (HTTP Secure)

    • SSH (Secure Shell)

    • RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol)

      SSH is used as an example.


  7. Enter the following information.

    • Restricted IP Addresses – Enter one or more allowed IP addresses, separating each address with a comma. Click Save.

    • Specific Domains – Enter one or more specific domains (if any), separating each with a comma. Click Save.

    • TCP Ports – Enter one or more TCP port numbers (if any), separating each with a comma. Click Save.

    • Note An additional option, Home Page URL, is available only for the HTTPS app type.

  8. Click Next to display the User Access tab.


  9. Click New.

  10. Under Type, select User or User Group.

    • If you selected User, choose either All (to allow access to all users) or Selected (to allow access by users you specify by their valid email addresses). Then click Save.


    • If you selected User Group, choose the user groups for which to allow access. Select the groups from the directories listed. Click Add, then click Save to save the user groups you added.


  11. Click Next and click Save.


Assigning an environment for the application‌

To assign an environment for the application, modify the cloud application settings as follows.

  1. Go to Administration > App Management and open the onboarded application by clicking the pencil icon.

  2. Go to the Environment page.

  3. Select the ZTNA environment for which you enabled network level access and configured network category (based on where the app is residing).

  4. Click Save.


    Checking the status of a Secure Private Access (ZTNA) tunnel‌

    To check the status of the ZTNA tunnel, go to Administration > Node Management. You can see the ZTNA Tunnel status for the desired ZTNA connector.


    For more information, see Setting up and managing nodes - on-premise deployments table. See these topics for more information and instructions about onboarding cloud applications:

    • Onboarding cloud applications and suites

    • Accessing cloud applications through the Secure Cloud Workspace

    • Post-onboarding tasks


      Connecting to remote machines using SSH and RDP‌

      Perform the steps in the following sections to connect to remote machines using SSH or RDP.


      Browser-based support for SSH and RDP

      Browser-based support for SSH (Secure Shell) and RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol) communication protocols enables users to access remote machines securely from a browser.

      Benefits of browser-based SSH communication:

    • Remote users can access their development environments from a browser.

    • Users can perform all activities supported in an SSH session.

      Benefits of browser-based RDP communication:

      Remote users can access a Windows remote desktop from a browser.

    • Administrators can configure policies for specific desktops and restrict user activities on those desktops.


For SSH

Note Lookout supports OpenSSH 8.2 or lower for SSH over Secure Private Access. The SSH over Secure Private Access supports RSA and DSA keys.

  1. From the Management Console, go to Home > Secure Cloud Workspace.

  2. Click the arrow icon on the SSH application.


  3. Click New.


  4. Enter a Connection Name.

  5. Enter the Host Name or IP.

    Note The IP address you enter must be within the range you specified in the Restricted IP addresses section when you onboarded the application.

  6. Enter the Port number. This number must be within the range you specified when you onboarded the application.

  7. Click Save & Connect. Alternatively, you can click Save and then click the Connection name from the list of saved connections.

  8. Enter the credentials for proxy authentication.


    1. Enter the Username of the server to which you want to connect.

    2. Select a credential type for access. You can choose either a Password or a Private Key.

      If you select Private Key, click the Choose file button when it appears, and select a .pem file to upload.

      If a Passphrase is associated with this private key (this association is optional), enter it.


  9. Click Connect.

You can now view the console (SSH) of the remote machine in the browser window.

Note Because existing SSH applications will no longer work, you must delete them and onboard the new SSH applications.


For RDP

  1. From the Management Console, go to Home > Secure Cloud Workspace.

  2. Click the arrow icon on the RDP application.


  3. Click New.


  4. Enter a Connection Name.

  5. Enter the Host Name or IP.

    Note This IP address must be within the range you specified in the Restricted IP addresses section when you onboarded the application.

  6. Enter the Port number. This number must be within the range you specified when you onboarded the application.

  7. Click Save & Connect. Alternatively, you can click Save and then click the Connection Name from the list of saved connectors.

  8. Enter the credentials for proxy authentication.

  9. Enter the Username and Password for the remote desktop machine to which you want to connect.

  10. Select the Ignore Certificate checkbox. When this box is checked, the certificate returned by the server will be ignored even if that certificate cannot be validated. This option is useful if you universally trust the server and your connection to it, and you know that the server’s certificate cannot be validated (for example, if it is self-signed).


  11. Click Connect.

You can now view the desktop of the remote computer in the browser window.


Restart or uninstall the on-premise enterprise connector as needed‌

Run these commands any time you need to restart or uninstall the Node Server.


To restart the Node Server

sudo service node-server restart sudo service strongswan restart sudo service node-server restart

To uninstall the Node Server

Run the following commands for Ubuntu:

sudo service strongswan stop

sudo apt remove enterprise-connector

Review the section Monitoring Secure Private Access activity and policy violations for options for monitoring Secure Private Access-related activity in the Management Console.

Note

Before shutting down the VM or deleting the VM, use the following stop commands to gracefully shut down the connector.

  • Shut down strongSwan and Node Server using the following commands:

    sudo service strongswan stop sudo service node-server stop

  • If the connector VM needs to be restarted, follow these steps.

    1. Before you shut down the VM, run these stop commands:

      sudo service strongswan stop sudo service node-server stop

    2. Once the VM is restarted, run these start commands:

sudo service strongswan start sudo service node-server start

Upgrading the Secure Private Access (ZTNA) connector manually using a Debian package‌

Perform these steps to upgrade the ZTNA connector that was previously installed using a Debian package on the Ubuntu OS:

  1. From the Management Console, go to Administration > System Settings > Downloads.

  2. Click the download icon for the On-premise Connector - Debian package for Ubuntu.

  3. Copy the downloaded Debian package to the Node Server on which you want to upgrade.

  4. Log in to the Node Server.

    Note: If you are upgrading from a version lower than 22.10.519 to version 22.10.519 or higher, you must remove strongswan and strongswan-starter packages. Also, perform this step if this step was not performed previously when you upgraded to the 22.10.519 version.

  5. Before upgrading the ZTNA connector, stop the IPSec tunnel, strongswan, and node-server services.

  6. Stop the IPSec tunnel:

    sudo ipsec stop

  7. Stop the following services:

    sudo service strongswan stop sudo service node-server stop

  8. Run the following command as a non-root user to upgrade the connector:

    sudo apt upgrade ./enterprise-connector_<connector_version>.deb

    Where <connector_version> is the connector version that you downloaded.

    Example:

    sudo apt upgrade ./enterprise-connector_22.10.0-417_amd64.deb

  9. When the following popup is displayed, click Yes.


  10. When the following popup is displayed, click Yes.


  11. Start the server services in the following sequence:

    Note: Remove strongswan and strongswan-starter packages if you are upgrading from a version lower than 22.10.519 to version 22.10.519 or higher.

    sudo apt remove strongswan

    sudo apt remove strongswan-starter sudo service node-server start


    Debugging options for Secure Private Access‌

    The following debug settings are available for Secure Private Access.

    • Log Download

    • Watchdog Settings

    • Debugging Settings

    • Har Logging

For detailed information, refer to the Debugging Nodes section.


Enterprise Application Discovery for Secure Private Access (ZTNA)‌

Enterprise Application Discovery for Secure Private Access enables security analysts to see and catalog private applications users are trying to access, and block applications according to their organization’s security needs. When users request access to an application, Secure Private Access can discover those applications using specific domain names and IP subnets.

Go to Home > Discover > Enterprise App Discovery to view the Enterprise App Discovery dashboard. The Dashboard page includes three tabs. The following sections describe the information in each tab.


Dashboard‌

The dashboard includes the following graphs that display data about discovered applications and users. Hover over any point in each graph to view additional details for that point.

  • Activity: A vertical line graph that shows the volume of activity for the time range you selected.

  • Enterprise Applications: A vertical line graph that shows a count of enterprise applications discovered over time.

  • Users: A vertical line graph that shows a count of users over time.

  • Top 10 App Types by Activity: A circle graph that shows the total volume of activity and the volume of SSH and HTTPS activity.

  • Top 10 Applications with Highest Activity: A bar graph that shows the highest volumes, size of activity, and user count by application IP subnet.

  • Top 10 Applications with Highest Activity: A bar graph that shows the user count and activity size by application IP subnet.

    At the left, you can select search filters for time range, user name, and environment name. Click the

    Reset link at the top left to clear the search criteria and enter new criteria. Click the Refresh icon at the upper right to update the data on the page.

    Discovered Applications‌

    From the Discovered Applications page, you can view information about enterprise applications. The page shows

  • the application name.

  • the Secure Private Access (ZTNA) environment name for the application.

  • the application type.

  • the most recent time that a user accessed the application.

  • the protocol and port.

  • the number of users accessing the application.

  • the total number of hits.

    For details about a specific application, click its name to display an Application Details page, which shows

  • the time a user last accessed the application.

  • the app URL if available.

  • the valid user email address.

  • client and origin request and response volume (in bytes).

  • source and client IP subnets.

  • protocol type.

    Click the left arrow at the top of the page to return to the Discovered Applications page.


    Users‌

  • From the Users page, you can view information about users of discovered applications. For each user, the page shows

  • the user's valid email address.

  • the number of applications the user accessed. Click the hyperlinked number to view the information about the application the users accessed.

  • The inbound, outbound, and total traffic volume (in kilobytes) for the user.

  • To return to the Users page, click the Users hyperlink at the left above the application details.


    User Groups‌

    From the User Groups page, you can view information about the user groups for discovered applications. For each user group, the page shows

  • the name of the user group.

  • the number of users in the group.

  • the number of applications accessed by users in that group.

  • the inbound, outbound, and total traffic volume for the users in that group.

    To filter columns, click the Column Filter icon at the upper right and select the columns to remove from the view.

    To download a CSV file of the page content, click the Download icon at the upper right.

    Configuring     traffic     steering          ‌


    Lookout provides several options for configuring how data moves through your organization, and how the security platform inspects and processes that traffic. This section provides information and instructions for managing traffic steering through the Management Console and through desktop clients.


    This section covers the following topics:


  • Creating and managing enterprise sites

  • Managing traffic steering for Lookout clients

    • In the Management Console

    • From the Windows client


Creating and managing enterprise sites‌

You can inspect traffic from sites in your organization that send data to cloud applications such as Box, Salesforce, or Office 365 or to other Internet destinations. You can define sites that identify locations such as branch offices. Each site definition you create directs traffic from that site to the security platform, which inspects and processes it based on security policies configured for the destination applications.


Example: If your organization has four branch offices, you can define each branch office as a site. You can then configure a tunnel for each site that specifies how traffic will be directed from that site to the security platform before the data goes to its destination.


For each site for which you need to configure traffic steering, you can create a new enterprise site from the Management Console (Enterprise Integration > Enterprise Sites).


Creating a new enterprise site for traffic tunneling‌

Perform the following steps to configure traffic tunneling for each site in your organization.


  1. Go to Administration > Enterprise Integration > Enterprise Sites and click New.

  2. Enter these basic details.

    • Name and Description – Enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional) for the site.

    • Location -- Enter location information (country and state or province as applicable).

    • Enter the Public IP address for the site and click Save to close the text box.

    • User count -- Select a range that represents the number of users at the site.

    • Traffic forwarding type – Select IPSec or Native endpoint steering (PAC, Agent).

    • FQDN -- Enter the Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) for the site. The FQDN maps to the Public IP address and provides a unique identifier for the site.

    • Private IP or subnet -- Identifies the source IP for the end user network through which the traffic is moving and helps to identify the correct tunnel to direct the traffic. For example, one site might use a desktop network while a second site might use a different subnet network. Sites can have the same or different subnets.

  3. Click Next.

  4. Enter the following encryption details.

    • Authentication method -- Select either Pre-Shared Key or Certificate.

    • A pre-shared key is shared between two endpoints. The keys on both endpoints must match for authentication to be successful.

      A pre-shared key can be generated automatically by clicking the icon to the right of the Pre-Shared Key field. This generated key is longer, more complex, and provides stronger security than a pre- shared key you create and enter yourself.

      If you enter a pre-shared key, the key should be between 8 and 64 characters long and include at least one lowercase character, one uppercase character, one numeric character, and one special character (for example, @ or %).

    • A certificate includes any certificate you have uploaded to Lookout SSE using Certificate Management. From the dropdown list, select a certificate to present for authentication. For information about creating and managing certificates, see Certificate Management.

    • IKE (Internet Key Exchange) -- IKE patterns are needed to establish tunnels. The native security platform uses the IKEV2 protocol.

    • FIPS Compliant -- Check the toggle to ensure that all IKE and IPsec cipher sites are FIPS compliant.

    • Encryption Algorithm -- Select from the list of available cipher sites. If you have enabled FIPS compliance, the list includes only compliant security options.

    • Diffie-Hellman Group -- Select a value from the list. The higher the number in the value, the stronger the security. If you enabled FIPS compliance, the list includes only compliant security options.

    • Life Time -- Enter the number of hours (between 10 and 72) for the IKE lifetime. The IKE expires after this number of hours. For example, if you entered 20 hours, the IKE expires after 20 hours. Before it expires, the tunnel goes through a renegotiation process.

  5. Click Next to configure advanced options.

  6. Under Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP), enter or select the following values.

    • Integrity and Encrypt algorithm -- Select a cipher site from the list.

    • ReKey -- Click the toggle to enable this option, which instructs the security platform to re-key the tunnel before the existing tunnel expires. The re-key process starts and the tunnel is re- negotiated. If this option is disabled, the tunnel is deactivated upon expiration and traffic cannot move through it.

    • ReAuth – Click the toggle to re-authenticate the two endpoints. This option is a recommended best practice to strengthen protection if either or both endpoints change or if the site has been compromised.

    • Depending on the selected authentication method, you can revoke access to the tunnel in two ways:

      • If you are using pre-shared keys, they will no longer match after they are changed when

        Reauth is enabled. A compromised site cannot connect with the security platform.

      • If you are using a certificate, you can remove or change the certificate.

    • Life Time -- Defines the lifetime of the tunnel itself. The tunnel life expires after the number of hours you enter. The value must be between 2 and 72 hours. This lifetime has a smaller minimum value (2 hours as opposed to 10 hours for the IKE lifetime) to enable a quicker end to a tunnel life, thus helping to prevent a tunnel from being compromised.

    • Dead peer detection -- Serves as a monitor of traffic "heartbeat," to detect the absence of traffic on a tunnel. The options for DPD action are:

    • None (default) -- Disables sending of active DPD messages.

    • Clear -- Closes the connection; no further action is taken.

    • Hold -- Installs a trap policy, which catches matching traffic and tries to renegotiate the connection on demand.

    • Restart -- Triggers an attempt to renegotiate the connection.

    • IKE Fragmentation -- A key exchange might include a large amount of data per packet. For example, a data packet might be larger than the Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU), which is the largest size frame or packet (approximately 1500 bytes for Ethernet links) that can be transmitted across a data link. Fragmentation allows the packet to be broken down into subpackets for transmission through the tunnel. Both endpoints must support fragmentation.

      The options are:

    • Yes (allow fragmentation)

    • Accept (if fragmentation occurs on the Lookout side, the other endpoint will accept it)

    • Force (if the packet size is known to be larger than the MTU, force fragmentation)

    • No (do not allow fragmentation).

  7. Click Save. The new site definition is added to the list on the Enterprise Sites page.

    A popup window displays tunnel configuration information, including Primary DNS and Secondary DNS information defined for the site. You can configure a tunnel for both a primary and a secondary DNS. The secondary DNS can serve as a backup to keep traffic moving if the primary tunnel goes down.

    • The Status field shows Disconnected or Connected status.

    • If the primary tunnel is connected, the status is displayed as connected.


Once tunnels are defined, you can set up and configure web and application policies in the Management Console to determine the appropriate actions for traffic moving through the tunnel.


High Availability support‌

SSE supports both Active/Standby and Active/Active high availability topologies with enterprise sites. Enterprise administrators can establish two IPsec VPN tunnels over each Wide Area Network (WAN) link to the primary and secondary Lookout SSE points of presence (POPs). These tunnels operate in an Active/Standby mode. Traffic is first forwarded over the Active tunnel to the primary POP. If the Active tunnel is terminated for some reason, the Standby tunnel can forward traffic to the secondary POP.


Enterprise sites having multiple WAN links can establish tunnels from each WAN to the primary and secondary Lookout SSE POPs. All tunnels to the primary SSE POP can operate in an Active/Active mode. SSE forwards the return traffic over the same tunnel it received from the enterprise site.

Configuring known locations‌

If traffic is coming from a known location (a branch office), users do not need to provide a tenant identifier. If you are using Secure Internet Access in explicit proxy mode with multiple tenants, you can define the locations where the traffic will be forwarded in explicit proxy mode. The proxy then can map the traffic from a location to your organization and apply policies accordingly.


Managing traffic steering for Lookout clients‌

In the SSE Management Console, you can configure settings for client devices by creating steering policies that include steering configurations. For each steering policy, you can specify traffic configurations to define those policies. Example: if you need web traffic from all Windows users in Europe to go to our security platform for protection, you can create a steering policy for that traffic.

The following sections provide instructions for creating traffic steering configurations and applying them to traffic steering policies.


Creating steering configurations‌

  1. Go to Enterprise Integration > Lookout Clients.

  2. Click the Steering Configuration tab.

  3. Click New.

  4. In the Basic page, enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional) for the steering configuration and click Next to display the Context page.

  5. To enable enterprise access, click the Enterprise Access toggle.

    From the Allowed Environment(s) dropdown list, select the list of environments that can be accessed by clients.

    Note: Only those environments for which the Enable Network Level Access option is enabled are shown in the Allowed Environment(s) dropdown list.

    The Enable Network Level Access option is located under Environment Management > Connector Settings > ZTNA.

  6. To enable users to control Internet access, click the Internet Access toggle. Fill in the new fields as follows:

  7. Select Internet Traffic Type from the dropdown list.

    • Internet Traffic (all ports, all protocols)

    • Web Traffic (port 443/80, HTTPS/Http)

    • Managed App Traffic

    • SaaS App Traffic (managed and unsanctioned apps)

    • Custom Traffic

  8. If you selected Custom Traffic:

    1. Select the default option of Domains as the context type.

    2. Select one or more domains by checking those to include.

    3. Click Save to close the domains list.

  9. (Optional) Select any traffic exceptions by selecting a context type for those exceptions – Domains, IP, or Process.

    To specify domains, IPs, or Processes, go to Protect > Category Management.

  10. Click Next to display summary information for the configuration. Click Save if the information is correct, or Previous to make any corrections.

The new configuration appears in the Steering Configuration page. You can apply this configuration to traffic steering policies you create.

Note: If users access enterprise web applications from Secure Cloud Workspace on an endpoint with an active Lookout Client (both Secure Internet Access and Secure Private Access tunnels are ON), the app access fails.

To make this scenario work, the admin needs to add lkt.cloud domains to bypass the list in the traffic steering config. This new configuration would start reporting the device as “Unmanaged” if there is no device certificate on the endpoint. In order to have the device report as “Managed”, the admin needs to ensure the device certificate is available on the device.


Creating traffic steering policies‌

  1. Go to Enterprise Integration > Lookout Clients.

  2. Click the Steering Policy tab.

  3. Click New.

  4. In the Basic Details page, enter a Name (required) and a Description (optional) for the steering policy.

  5. From the dropdown list, select a Steering Configuration. The selections come from the configurations you created in the Steering Configuration page.

  6. To allow users to control Internet access, click the Allow End User to Control Internet Access

    toggle.

  7. Click Next.

  8. In the Context page, select a Context Type -- Enterprise Sites, Users, User Group, Location, Device Profile, or Device OS.

  9. Select a Context for the selected Context Type. Example: For Device Profile, select Managed Status, Compliance Status, or Threat Status. Then, select a Target – Managed or Unmanaged.

  10. (Optional) Select any Context Exceptions – Users, User Group, or Location.

  11. Click Next to view the summary information for the policy. Click Save if the information is correct, or Previous to make any corrections.

    Viewing and configuring device information‌


    From the Lookout Client tab of the Device Management page (Protect > Device Management), you can view information about each device, including the device ID and host name, users associated with the device, cloud applications, traffic steering configurations for the device, posture status, EDRM access settings, and Internet and Enterprise connection status for the device.

    For each device, you can click the icons in the Action column to perform the following actions:
